reviewText:
I friend gifted me this game so I just wanted to shout out a big thanks to him!

This game... is awesome. I love the concept. Created by Behold Studios, Chroma Squad is essentially a Power Rangers management sim. You get to make your own squad and customize your team to fit your desires of having one of the best or lamest Sentai teams ever!

The story is that a bunch of stuntmen quit their old job because they believe their director lacks creativity and want more creative freedom. The plot really goes off the rails later on but it's fun to watch. The dialogue of your team is super corny but I loved it however if that's not your thing then it might be something to consider if you're planning on getting Chroma Squad. The dialogue is filled with puns, references and enough fourth wall jokes to make Deadpool blush.

Visually it looks nice, it's some nice pixel graphics. I don't think they use it as a lazy excuse since it's nice good to look at and there is detail in the game. Not the heaviest but enough to distinguish everything easily. The music is personally one of the best parts of the game. This is some really good chiptune music, it has some great soundtracks that get you pumped up for a boss battle and my personal favourite This is Cerebro" is so campy and so catchy.

The gameplay itself
date: when fighting is a tactical RPG. A pretty fun one
recommended: the game has an emphasis on team attacks which is pretty cool and works with the theme. You got abilities and cool weapons for the different classes to play around with and a cool chunk of bosses. You also get finishing moves for them which is pretty sweet as well. One thing that does bother me a bit is that a lot of the time the game can be too easy but then there is a huge difficulty spike in the last level. What is that all about?\n\nWhen not in normal combat you're doing one of two things. The first is managing your studio
hoursPlayed: it's fun as you have to upgrade the studio
helpfulPercent: hire agencies to promote your show
votesHelpful: check emails and all that managment sim stuff. The other is the mech combat. It wouldn't be Power Rangers without a giant mech battle in almost every episode. It can be fun but really it just comes down to chance whether attack or block attacks. It looks cool but it's pretty shallow.\n\nTo conclude my mad ramblings I of course like this game a lot! It's one of those games I wished I played earlier when it came out last year. If you understand the basic core material you'll have a lot of fun with it.  If you've never heard of Power Rangers AT ALL or know exactly ziltch about it then I wouldn't reccommend this to you. Otherwise you should definitely get it! It's a game that's about having fun rather than being amazingly unique or difficult (for the most part). I give this an 8.5/10"

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G_8TK2LmynQ

It’s a tactical RPG with base-building strategy elements that follows the story of five stuntmen who leave their second banana positions to make their own martial arts TV show. Like Knights of Pen and Paper, Chroma Squad has retro-inspired graphics and music, and spends a lot of time breaking the fourth wall and poking fun at pop culture tropes.

I personally felt that Knights of Pen and Paper, while it had some charm, went on for far too long without shaking anything up, ultimately weakening what might have been a charming experience by overstaying its welcome. And while Chroma Squad sometimes suffers from a similar affliction, I feel that Behold Studios learned a hell of a lot, tightening and producing an RPG that is just plain fun to play.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Wonderful little tactical RPG game where you control a team of actors with their own show where they fight monsters, which starts coming true as time goes on.

The meat of the game is the tactical turn based combat, and as someone who really enjoys this type of gameplay this is right up my alley. There are also some RPG elements outside of combat, such as allocating skill points, crafting and buying upgrades.

After completing most maps you join together and go into a giant mecha to fight the boss of the map again, with a different combat style which is focused on timing the hits and using a limited number of different abilities. This is a nice addition for the first few times, however it is not nearly as fleshed out and feels like an after thought. And seeing as how you have to do a bunch of these fights I'm quite sure everyone will get tired of them before the end of the game.

The story is reasonably entertaining, although it can become tiresome to follow since it is delivered solely through text boxes of the main characaters, and you have to wait for each one to finish scrolling in order to move on to the next one. So if you read much faster than the game scrolls then you're going to have to do a lot of waiting. There is an option to fast forward through everything, however it is not really useful if you still want to follow the story since the fast forward skips everything.

And the game does go a little overboard with the pixel artstyle, I certainly would have liked more definition and fluid animations. Also the overall design starts to become stale with time, especially since this is quite a long game.

I would easily recommend Chroma Squad to any fan of the tactical turn based combat style.

7 / 10

reviewText:
Chroma Squad, a game that gave me a quad heart attacak.

Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG, which has quite the fast download baud. But there is more, because the thing about it that earned my immediate apllause, is that it is parodying sentai with several references throughout, which made me glad, but I have sadly found a lot of accidental hentai.
Super sentai, or to the duper americans power rangers, are shows about various dangerous threatening the world with a shower of monsters. So it is up to three to six teammates, to bring an end to the evils killing spree. The difference between sentai, and the ignorance of power rangers are huge, mostly in terms of violence because lord knows how hard mothers bother, they somehow still seek something that will make them take the offense and write angry letters.

The basic of the plot that quickly forms a blood clot, is five stunt actors are getting the brunt end of the stick from the director, mostly because the real actors are mostly spectators now. They get sick of this repetitive shtick, so they decide that instead they shouldn't bide their time, they quit on the spot leaving the old studio to rot, to start their own, though they bring their former director down by stealing the suits.

Earth is under threat, but like a stoners baguette the heroes take a long time to learn, and until then they are quite stern about this all being special effects, or defects. They use the footage of them fighting aliens, to get their show more lighting. I won't go further, because this does go deeper but is actually simple to follow, which is a nice dimple of quirks that I love.

The tactical gameplay, is actually quite practical. Like a cannibal feret, you can use teamwork to attack, step back, or get teammates closer or in positions you would rather see in your vision. You have a variety of not only weapons, you have a small soceity of actors to pick from, obviously some fit better into each role of the five, it is up to you to put down that tea cup and to decide which loon becomes a front line goon or a back line maroon. But you also have directors instruction to follow, which you should unless your skull is hollow. Or you'll be low on money, and despite the amount you will quickly blow through it. Items are dropped, as long as you aren't stopped from murdering aliens. Which can be used to upgrade your zord, or create weapons and armor out of cardboard.

Though you must not forget, because you can't bet all your cash on weapons and shiny gear, to try and make the enemies fear you. You have to handle a studio, since you are the borough. You can pay for better green screens, shop association, contracts for promotions that last up to three episodes before abdication. Upgrading health care, so that your squad will fair better when taking hits, or upgrade the workshop to get more tiny bits to craft with. One thing I do enjoy, which was quite a clever ploy. Are the letters you receive, after each episode you achieve, you have fan mail to answer, and if you do it without fail you gain fans, money, or more funny as it is I rather support telling your director off when he threatens to take you to court.

This game is great, though unfortunately fate can't make everything perfect. The zord battles are the main issue, I did rip a few tissues at them...At first, but aside from that I did not have a thirst for anymore, because they were slow where you just click a button to deal a combo of blows. No strategy or thought, but despite the upgrades you bought, even if you take a hard hit an yelp, and run out of health, you call your fans for help. They give you health, which was quite a bother to me to know there was no stealth to the threat. It meant I could mess up, without having to fess up any real significant consequences.

That aside this game is grand, and all of the humor and references make it far from bland. Out of all the sentai references, the one that more so instantly hit my preferences, was a statue greater than sweet bubblegum, that was dedicated to big 1, from Jack-Q the second super sentai.

Otherwise can recommend.

reviewText:
Chroma Squad is simply a love letter to what Power Rangers use to be. It has action, comedy, interesting writing, and anything you would want from a PR game. You start out as 5 stuntmen who have recently quit their jobs doing sentai stunts to form their own studio. When you get into the studio thats when the real magic begins. Once there, you're able to design your own suits and mechas, something I'm sure any PR fan has dreamed of.

You're also able to respond to fan letters and control your fan market to some extent by choosing from a wide selection of advertaisment firms. When you go into battle this game is a mix of an RTS and Turn Based RPG ala Pokemon. The RTS side is used for your simple ranger battles where each class has a variety of skills at their disposal, which grow as the story progresses. You're also able to do showy finishing moves on the bosses in true sentai fashion. My only problem with the RTS board is that sometimes you can't see parts of the grid because they're blocked by objects on the field.
The game then becomes much closer to a TurnBased RPG when in mecha form where you're allowed to hit your opposing monster a certain number of times before a hit misses and they hit back. But, all is not lost when they hit back theres a system that if you time it correctly and click in the white area of the bar you can block some of the damage. Think Gears of War's reload system. Everyonce in awhile though this bar lags causing you to get hit by the full blunt of the attack without a chance to stop it.

TL;DR:The Story and writing are amazing and are VERY PR like. The RTS combat while fun has some issues with grid square blocking, nothing gamebreaking though. The mecha combat is far slower than the RTS combat but still quite fun

Score: 8.6/10

reviewText: I...I ♥ this game so much. So. Much.
voteText: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
It’s not often that one show can take control of an entire generation. For my childhood it was Power Rangers… This multi-cultural love-letter to nostalgia took over many homes in the 90s with force. Its flimsy morals and clunkily scripted acting were apparently exactly what most of the world was looking for, as we stumbled out of the cocaine-fueled haze that was the 80s. There are very few shows today that manage to galvanize fans in such massive numbers. Maybe Spongebob comes close, but he’s a crossdresser who lives inside of a fruit. Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG about a tokusatsu show similar to Power Rangers. Each character has a specialized role, but are able to be slightly customized to your liking depending on the actor/equipment you choose. Chroma Squad does have a few blemishes, but is an overall amazing experience. Will it hold up for those who aren’t wearing nostalgia goggles? Let’s find out as we look deeper at Chroma Squad.

Fantastic retro style coats Chroma Squad, from the graphics to the music. While the gameplay starts out feeling extremely simple, it quickly deepens as the odds are stacked ever-higher against you. After moving you can attack, move a second time, or prepare for teamwork. Teamwork is an awesome aspect that allows your characters to toss each other around in fantastic acrobatics, or prepare a combo attack on an adjacent enemy. Teamwork attacks are an absolute necessity, as later enemies take multiple attacks to defeat. Aside from fantastic agility and teamwork, the Chroma Squad doesn’t have much in the way of firepower when they’re in their 28-year-old-teenager form. However, once per fight though, you can Chromatize. Transformation not only fully heals all your characters, but also unlocks a variety of special abilities. Every season you will unlock a couple of new skills to pick from, and this extends the replayability of Chroma Squad greatly.

The fights take place in a variety of sets. Some are fantastic to look at, with a variety of hazards. Others are completely stark with nothing on display except for a couple lighting guys and key grips using their bellies to knock bowls of mac’n’cheese off of the craft service table. At least that’s what I like to imagine. The gameplay grows even deeper as you realize there are a variety of director actions you will need to follow during the combat in order to maximize your audience and gain new fans. Chroma Squad isn’t all about high-flying action though. Between episodes you will need to craft equipments and gear up your heroes, choose between a variety of marketing agents with tons of different boosts, and assemble your mecha to do battle when your enemies go super-size. The management aspect is extremely interesting, and while praying to RNGsus while crafting for a decent upgrade can become a bit frustrating, it again does wonders to extend the replayability.

I’ve sung so much praise for Chroma Squad that I am loathe to point out the low points, but it is about that time in the review. The majority of the controls are point and click, which can be a bit of a drain when sitting for extended play sessions. The less-inspired set designs seriously break my heart, as there is much more potential than a big empty room. The story does alright, aside from some pretty blatant SJW messaging in the beginning. It might be tongue in cheek. I can really only hope. Overall I think Chroma Squad is an experience worth having, especially if you were raised on Power Rangers or Big Bad Beetleborgs or VR Troopers. There really were just a plethora of these shows on in the 90s. This is why it’s pretty obvious to me why this game was so easily kickstarted, and I am positively overjoyed that Behold Studios was able to bring Chroma Squad very close to its full potential. I really do hope to see a sequel sometime in the future.

Gameplay:

Controls- 6/10
Fun Factor- 9/10
Difficulty- 8/10
Replayability- 7/10
Innovation- 10/10

Aesthetic:

Graphics- 9/10
Music- 10/10
Sound FX- 8/10
Story/Lore- 7/10
Level Design- 6/10

Final Score: 80/100 for innovation, graphics, and fun factor.
Summary: Fantastic tactical RPG infused with humor and deceptively-deep gameplay.
Verdict: Amazing fun. Not as replayable as something like Final Fantasy Tactics, but still worth a look.

Full text/photo review: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-chroma-squad/
Full review video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J5JHWQLc0zo

reviewText:
I don't generally write steam reviews, but I felt compelled to do on this case.

I'll keep this short. First of all, if you're looking for gameplay, Chroma Squad has a semi-decent system going for it. In fact, it's quite fun. Not overtly complex, but it gets the game moving. Figths have some interesting mechanics to them, and you generally won't find yourself being bored. Gameplay wise, it's fine. A Seven out of ten, generally.

The reason I'm giving this game a negative review however, are these two.

First of all - and, I suppose, the less important one. The writing. It attempts to be this cheesy script played for laughs, but all it does is give you cringeworthy references that batffle you at just how badly they are handled. The kickstarter backer appearances are laughable and ham fisted. I'd actually feel embarassed for backing this and being put on it as it was.

It says it's an affectionate parody/homage to Sentai, but it instead feels like it's trying too hard.

Now, you might say that you don't give a crap about the writing and that's fine. It's a videogame. So what's my second complaint?

How awfully BUGGY the game is, and in the worst ways imaginable. It has a tendency to constantly shut down, crash ,or simply not do anything after a certain sequence of events happened. I've gritten my teeth and bore it for most of the game, but the last straw was, infact, at the very last mission of the game, composed of two long boss fights - the last one being especially long, lasting possibly hours. The game proceeded to crash on the first one, making me lose all progress. It then crashed again at the end of the second one, meaning it put three hours of gameplay to waste, as the game did not foresee it crashing, for whatever reason. That managed to make me give up on the game and not want to finish it. The fact that the bug report icon is ALWAYS there on the top right corner should actually tell you just how unstable this game is.

It's a fun game. It's an embarassing piece of writing, and an awfully coded mess that's unreliable at the worst moments.

UPDATE

After replaying the game post-patch, performance has indeed increased. I've encountered so far only minor visual bugs that did not break the game nor make it crash, so one can assume the stability of the game is indeed being improved. Previous complaints still apply, and the game still has a couple visual glitches, aswell as issues with the achievement unlock system, but right now, it's properly playable. With that done, I shift my opinion to a careful recommendation - if you're a fan of Sentai, you can probably buy it. If not, but you're really curious, wait for a sale.

reviewText: Retsu go

Chroma Squad is a light tactical RPG featuring a customizable cast of likeable goofballs. Anybody who remembers the Power Rangers and other sentai series knows the formula.

Bad Guy of the Week.
Mecha Battles.
Twelve gallon jugs of The Rule of Cool applied liberally.

Chroma Squad is bright, cheerful and a joy to play. The music (particularly the main menu) is catchy and consistent. The graphics are detailed and well crafted. The entire game is a gleeful joyride through a land of complete Space Ham and Cheese. The story is a bit sparce and delivered in broad strokes, but even that  pays homage to the old shows.

The tactical combat is simple but effective and polished. The teamwork aspect is one I would have loved to have in other games and makes for a solid engine to the entire system. Overall, the game left me with a pleasant impression and a smile on my face.

It also left me wanting more.

And that's a compliment rarely delivered earnestly in a crowded, overstuffed marketplace.

I want more.

Please, Chroma Squad. Fight on for great justice!
The earth still needs you.

reviewText: This one one of the greatest games of all time, I cannot recommend it enough!
Awesome game. I'm only on season 2. I was hoping characters could die...
Great references, great story, great gameplay features and customization, GREAT GAME.\nOh and don't even get me started about the giant chromas battles.

Have you ever wanted to be a Power Ranger?  Have you ever wanted to direct the action of the Power Rangers?  Have you ever wanted to see it all play out in old school pixelated graphics?  Have you ever wanted to manage a film studio and also have an anthropomorphic beaver on your team?  Chroma Squad might be for you then...  If you haven't wanted these things, you should still check it out.  It is a pretty fun turn based combat game with some management simulation and strategy built in.  The graphics are fun, the story is funny and witty, and the game is light and good natured.  If you are looking for more information you can check out my YouTube series on the game at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9PeJP4NzAFo.\n\nEnjoy!

Behold Studio has done it again. A delightful RPG with deceptive depth, Chroma Squad hits home. The immersive squad customization, the upgrades and crafting options, the number of small facets that combine to create a whole much greater than the sum of its parts. If old school RPGs and the MMPRs are your bag, then absolutely worth buying. If you're not, you may still find plenty of enjoyment from this sneaky up-and-coming cult hit.

This is a great game.  I backed it as I was a big fan of tactics games like XCOM, but I had no idea it would be such a charming game.  It has great pixel-based art, a funny story, and a surprisingly good tactics engine based around teamwork".  Very happy to see a successful kickstarter indie game like this succeed."

Another great thing about this game is being able to customize your crew and the colors of each ranger. Morphing is awesome. Mecha battles are pretty freaking cool. Only con so far would be graphics, and being able to level and gain experience would be nice.

Chroma Squad is a Tactical-RPG (i.e.: Final Fantasy Tactics, Fire Emblem), coated with some Management Sim mechanics.

In Chroma Squad you control an independent Super Sentai Studio trying to create its first series. As such, you'll have to manage your money, buy upgrades to the studio, new clothes for your actors and hire people to take care of your marketing strategy.
The meat of the game, however, lies between these management sessions. Whenever you record an episode, the game becomes a tactical RPG: you start giving orders to your actors on where to move, who to attack, stuff like that.
It's an amazingly stylish game. The pixel-art is awesome, the soundtrack is pure chiptune bliss (plus a main theme with japanese lyrics!) and the game is packed with references to pop culture and super sentais in general.
You don't really need to be a super sentai fan to enjoy the solid tactics mechanics in this game, but it surely adds to the overall experience. I recommend this game to anyone who ever enjoyed a Power Rangers episode or is just itching for a new TRPG game.

TL;DR: Awesome Tactical-RPG with stylish graphics, soundtrack and references. If you like Super Sentais you'll fall in love with it!

Well, so far, it's been a great game. It's a love letter to tokusatsu shows, and to JUSTICE.

What I'm liking about it is that it doesn't really take itself seriously, and it's a bunch of people making their own series because they like it so much that they just had to do it. This is a game I didn't expect to want, yet I did. I'm glad I backed it on Kickstarter and see it deliver.

While it might have some grammar mistakes, the script so far is pretty good, and it has TONS of references to both SUPER SENTAI (which the game is definitely based on) and Power Rangers (what most of us Westerners know tokusatsu from). It even makes some slight jabs at some people, which is very brave to do.

10/10 would henshin again.

reviewText:
I was going to write a review for this in full but it turns out Steam has a character limit and I went a hell of a lot further than it allows.
Short version: buy this game, play this game, enjoy this game; you'll get your money's worth, but not much more.

Read the full review here: https://animelysis.wordpress.com/2015/06/19/taste-the-rainbow-reviewing-chroma-squad/

tl;dr -> I finally got to create my own squad of Power Rangers, OMG!

I was fortunate to receive multiple review/press copies from the developing team, and I was very excited to play as a squad of television stars acting as super heroes akin to the Power Rangers. I was thoroughly satisfied with my gameplay experience.

If you enjoy retro pixel graphics, role-playing games (RPG), squad-based tactical combat, superheroes, kaiju, and management mechanics (television studio), then you will absolutely adore Chroma Squad.

The aesthetics are fantastic - the amount of detail in every model and object is very high. The sound effects and music are good and add a lot to the retro feel. You can even fast-forward cutscenes and it will appear like a VHS (if you were alive to remember what those are lol) tape. The story is funny and decent, and there is a very good twist that recaptured my attention. Admittedly, near the end-game I would just fast-forward through any of the cutscenes. There are a number of choices you will encounter, changing the story and encouraging multiple playthroughs. I love how equipping different armor (helmet, boots, etc) and weapons actually changes the look of your characters - I have always been the biggest aesthetic ♥♥♥♥♥. A nice detail is how newer seasons introduce better equipment (like transitioning from handmade/cardboard equipment to plastic) - and the appearance of each item reflects the quality level. You also have a giant mech, and end-game mechs look so much more badass than the starting one. These aesthetics accurately capture your gameplay progression from a low-budget mom & pop company to a AAA brand.

Controls are easy to learn and typical of turn-based tactics games. The tutorials are very informative and every element of the game is explained well enough so that you won't have to look up guides (unless you want some extra tips). The learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with turn-based tactical games - the most challenging part of the game is maintaining your entire studio (specifically, your equipment) properly match the enemy's prowess after each episode. Each season is split into multiple episodes, and new seasons introduce new enemies, equipment, and other things.

Gameplay begins in the studio, where you can craft/buy equipment for your actors/mech to use, upgrade items in the studio for bonuses, and purchase marketing teams (which provide further bonuses). You can customize your actors and actresses' names and the catchphrases they use - like when they transform or summon their mech. As you progress through the TV show seasons, you will unlock more items to craft, buy, and upgrade. There are crates you can buy that provide random crafting materials in different tiers - crafting your own equipment is better in most cases because you also gain random attributes to your new items. Marketing teams you select will grant you bonuses depending on how many fans you have (gained after each level/episode depending on how well you perform and if you complete secondary objectives). Emails are answered in the studio hub, and some of your choices will affect future storylines and opportunities.

When you are finished outfitting your team, you can select from different episodes to act out - some will feature mech vs. kaiju battles, others may have a guest ally appear. Secondary objectives may include defeating x enemies before transforming (once you select transform
date: your team will move close together and switch to their Power Ranger-like forms), executing x team moves, or winning in x turns. Completing these tasks will grant you a bonus to fans, but missing them will not deduct anything; however, you lose fans whenever a squad member is downed (brought to 0 health). In order to transform, you need to gain enough audience power (think of it as active viewers) to fill your transform" gauge. There are marketing companies that give you a starting boost to this gauge
recommended: accelerating how quickly you can transform.\n\nDuring combat
hoursPlayed: you will issue orders one-at-a-time for each member - once you are finished
helpfulPercent: followed by the next round. You can have your characters use "teamwork
votesHelpful: which allows you to chain together team attacks and increase the movement range of other actors/actresses. You will execute a special attack if every member of your squad attacks the same target, and you will perform a super attack if every member uses a weapon. Episodes are usually split into multiple parts, and subsequent parts will have you continue with refilled health. For some episodes, you will end with a mech battle mini-game.\n\nThe mini-game is my most favorite part - you and the enemy kaiju take turns attacking. Whenever you attack, it reduces the accuracy (but increases the damage multiplier) of the next attack. Furthermore, chaining a long attack increases the multiplier for anything you decide to do, so a good idea is to balance offence and defence - if you defend" with a high multiplier
votesTotal: you will negate much of your opponent's damage. Your multiplier also affects any special attacks you have. If you get greedy

reviewText: Very fun game to play on steam link. Relaxing and fun, but also simple. Not very tasking of my computer. The controller support is great as well.

A delightful second venture from an incredible team, Chroma Squad follows the adventures of a stunt team from a Sentai series as they either become real heroes or get really into character. The game has multiple paths and endings and excellent replay value, with very strong core mechanics. The introduction of the 'directors instructions' system adds a lot of variety and depth to the tactics genre, making every fight feel fresh.\n\nFantastic mechanics, a lighthearted and fun theme, solid replay value, and an excellent sound track. Behold Studios are showing themselves to be masters of the lighthearted indie aesthetic again and again.

This game is fantastic.
Lots of nostalgia for anyone growing up watching power rangers. There isnt much strategy to the game but just enough to make it enjoyable though you wont be smacking your head against the wall because it is difficult. Sometimes completing all the director's instructions can be a chore but if you dont care about that and just want to 'win' than it will be a piece of cake...unless you play on the hardest difficulty, where you will need all the fans you can get to generate money and keep your studio floating.
There is definitely replayability because you can get a couple of different endings but it feels like most of the choices you make are small scale, it is a pretty linear story with some variations in my opinion.
Also, dont pay any attention to the gamergate types that complain about feminist tropes. There is one episode that has a guy kidnapped instead of a girl in the very beginning and it doesnt have any bearing on the rest of the plot, just the game creators making commentary on overplayed tropes.
Overall I would highly recommend this game to someone who loves strategy, RPGs, power rangers, and a few corny jokes.
10/10

reviewText: Charming and challenging with a great theme. Turn based strategies with strange gimmicks are always some of my favorite games, and this does not dissapoint. The interface seems designed to be touch screen ready, but it does not get in the way of gameplay using a mouse and keyboard. Kind of bummed that there isn't more agency over what you're filming, as this is very story based, but again, the gameplay is solid and enjoyable, which is impressive since turn based combat is so easy to mess up and make too boring or obtuse. Overall worth a buy. Looking forward to a sequel where you choose everything, from enemy costumes to backdrops and effects.

reviewText: If you love combiner robots, sentai shows, 80's graphics, stategy games, management sims, and time spanning pop culture references, then this is the game for you! I wouldn't let the source material get in the way for you, this is a light-hearted game, that can both make fun of what it is representing, as well as still pay honourable homage to it. my seal of approval, this game has.

reviewText: Great story and awesome customization!!! had a blast playing and rmemebering all the Power rangers times I had as a kid!

Alright so after doing a Let's Play on this game, I have to say for a game that had so many references from video games, anime and even toku.  I'm saying this now...SEQUEL-WORTHY!  This game remind so much of Lunar Silver Star Story because of the many references they threw in the game.  That, aside..with all the strategy games I ever done, I really enjoyed this game immensely and if I would do this game over, I would. But I would recommend this game only if you're a fan of tactical games, tokusatsu, or video games.  I could say this game could finished in less than a day if you did all of it in every difficulty, but that's clearly up to you.\n\nTo Behold Studios, THANK YOU! Please consider doing a sequel!

This a really cool, funny game. It's based on Power Rangers, so it's obviously already awesome just because of that, but the gameplay is what really makes me love it so much. This is a strategy game where your characters become more powerful by either (The long way...) crafting equipment you gain from various enemies, or (The easy capitalist way) paying for equipment at a shop. This game also has a few different possible endings, so that gives it some replay value, and since this game lets you choose different characters at the beginning as well as have your own play style, you shouldn't really be bored out of your mind replaying the game like I usually am with some other games. The price isn't really too much compared to what you get out of it, because there are a lot of ways you could customize your team to work with your play style (At least 3!.... Probably more, though...). Chroma Squad really gave me a lot of nostalgia, especially since I grew up watching Power Rangers, but I think I could really recommend this game to anyone who really likes any sort of strategy game or any sort of game where you can make important choices to decide what happens. Soooo.... This is a pretty good game, and, as a plus, the soundtrack is awesome!

The first time I played this game I was hooked until my laptop's battery died.

As someone who's been aching for a good game about tokusatsu for years, I can't think of a game that has ever given me so much childish glee.

The combat is fun, the presentation is excellent, and the management aspect is solid. Chroma Squad feels like it went down a checklist of damn-near everything I personally could ever want in a game. Power Rangers, giant robots, tactical combat, extensive customization, crafting... Even if some of these systems aren't individually excellent in their execution, together they create something truly special.
if you love fire emblem or final fantasy tactics, buy now

It's a very fun and enjoyable game and I would recommend it to anybody. However, there are a number of bugs and problems in the game that really should've been fixed after 10 months on the market. Enemies dodging or countering when something sets the probability of those happening to 0% (dazed bosses), skills not always working (e.g. Fast Reflexes), inaccurate skill descriptions (e.g. Multi-Shot working with rifles when described as only working with pistols), etc.\n\nNevertheless, none of the bugs or issues are completely gamebreaking and its still a fun game, though I am left with doubts in regards to the developers' enthusiasm and interest in the game by letting such blatant issues remain for so long.

Absolutely wonderful.

A demanding but fair gameplay wrapped up with some management stuff and a really funny plot.

Totally recommended if you like tactic RPGs and/or super hero tv shows (specially Bioman and Power Rangers).

The story certainly feels like a sentai, and I loved every minute of it. Gameplay was both fun and interesting. The TEAMWORK" command is a wonderful unique feature that makes Chroma Squad stand out amongst tactical RPGs. I feel like they spend too much time with meta dialogue

Sometimes completing all the director's instructions can be a chore but if you dont care about that and just want to 'win' than it will be a piece of cake...unless you play on the hardest difficulty, where you will need all the fans you can get to generate money and keep your studio floating.
There is definitely replayability because you can get a couple of different endings but it feels like most of the choices you make are small scale, it is a pretty linear story with some variations in my opinion.
Also, dont pay any attention to the gamergate types that complain about feminist tropes. There is one episode that has a guy kidnapped instead of a girl in the very beginning and it doesnt have any bearing on the rest of the plot, just the game creators making commentary on overplayed tropes.
Overall I would highly recommend this game to someone who loves strategy, RPGs, power rangers, and a few corny jokes.

This game is delightful. If you ever watched the Power Rangers as a kid, you are probably going to like this game. Basically, think Power Rangers meets Final Fantasy Tactics. And you are making a TV show. The combat isn't especially deep, nor is the studio management, but the package as a whole is great.

Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG where you use power ranger esque characters to fight monsters. so right off the bat it sounds awesome right? Well it is, it's really awesome but is it perfect? No. When the game is on the ground using its awesome sentai inspired battle system it sparkles like the sea. However each stage ends with a mecha fight, that is cool in theory but in practice it becomes a nightmare. Stages in this game usually take about an hour so after an hour of immensly satisfying tactical comabt where victory is decided by skill alone you are thrust into a situation where you could randomly lose all your progress and need to entirely restart the mission. This can leave you entirely dishearted as an hour of very intense gameplay can be thrown out the window. Aside from this however, the game is outstanding. looks great, sounds great and can lead to some very satisfying gameplay. You really should play this awesome game, but be ready from some seriously salty rage quits at the meccha battles.
Good stuff. Must buy if you like SRPGs and have a nostalgic weak spot for Power Rangers.

Got this game on sale for about $7.50
I've read a lot of reviews before purchasing it and as I've played through there were def bugs one even forced me to replay a level, and the jokes are hit or miss.

However, the game as a whole is pretty amazing. I enjoyed it very much and even got addicted to it.
This game is not overly challenging for fans of tactical/turn-base strategy RPGs and the right builds can make certain members of your team kind of OP.

Definitely worth $7.50 and looking forward to future patches/fixes/additions.

Do not be fooled by the small playing time that Steam shows. When I started playing this game for the first time, I was offline, and I played for 7 hours non-stop.

This game is a dream that come true!

When I was a kid, on the 90's I loved to watch tokusatsus (heroes in costumes, like Power Rangers, Super Sentai, Kamen Rider, etc..) and loved to play with my cousins like we were in the show.

If you're like me who always wanted to be the creator of your own tokusatsu show, here's your chance!

Chroma Squad is a beautiful game of tactical RPG  (a bit similar to Final Fantasy Tactics, or Tactics Ogre) where you control your own tokusatsu squad and studio in your way to become very successful and famous.

You can customize the colors, names, and choose the actors that will play them, and even what they say when they call their giant robot, or when they transform!

You equip items (that even change their appearance!) buying from the store, or creating from your workshop to become stronger, and choose wich skills each one will have. Each squad member have it's own role and skills. (There's the Lead, Assault, Scout, Techie and Support.)

If you watched tokusatsus you will notice many references, and the game have very funny conversations and events.

Even if you're not a fan, nor didn't watched any tokusatsu, I recomend this game if you like Tactical RPGs. You will love it!

Don't waste any more time, buy it and have tons of fun!

Now if you excuse me, the world need my help. Random Rangers, let's Randomize!

reviewText:
Really fun game with a lot of replay value.  Tactical RPG combat flows well and the team-up system leads to some fun things to do even while abilities are on cooldown.  Branching story paths make for some good incentive to play through multiple times.

Mecha battles are a little one-note, but still fun.  Crafting system seems to have bad drops, but with proper marketing choices and investing in some of the material packs you can make it work out.

My only complaints: YOU CANNOT UNDO ACTIONS, which is so frustrating sometimes, oh boy.  That's the number one problem for me.  Also there is not enough cool stuff to spend money on in the in-game store, as each tier boils down to defense armor" vs "offense armor".  Crafting has one or two interesting items (the Speed boots and the Team-Toss gloves) but there isn't a lot of variety outside of the gimmick items
date: when there could be a lot more going on.  More actor choices (and the ability to recast them mid-series) would be nice too
recommended: it feels like a very small pool of options.\n\nThe game also ends right when you start feeling very powerful so I'd like to see a 'New Series' mode (where you do a new team with a new storyline but keep your studio) or some sort of extra seasons.  Some way to keep going.  The game feels a little short.  A 'mission creator' and some sort of endless mode with escalating difficulty as seasons keep going on could fix this
hoursPlayed: and I believe the developers are looking into these sorts of ideas.\n\nIt's off to a great start
voteText: it's an awesome game for anyone into tactical RPGs or sentai/power rangers stuff
helpfulPercent: and I hope it keeps improving over time."

reviewText: A long overdue gift to those who grew up dreaming of making a Sentai series all their own. What Chroma Squad lacks in simulation elements it compensates with a neverending celebration of the best parts of Sentai new and old. If there is anything to pity its that Chroma Squad wasn't 3 different games and fans of Metal Heroes and Kamen Rider only get to revel in the last season of the storyline, but their inclusion shows just how much love Behold Studios has to offer, it can't be contained and oozes out of every scene! At the same time, if you step outside what the game celebrates you're left with an honest and simple Strategy RPG with map and encounter designs that genre veterans will find uninspired. The Episodes of the game are filled with colorful characters based on classic Sentai villains and antiheroes or pop culture and it is their presence and strength of personality that bring flavor to each individual Episode. So if you're prepared to be charmed, prepared to fall in love with the idea of being a team of costumed heroes, or prepared to be entertained by a campy throwback to how Sentai captures the hearts of children, Chroma Squad is absolutely the game you're after, look no further.

reviewText:
Pros

- The general look of the game is top notch. It's very appealing to look at.
- The soundtrack is decent, albeit forgetable.
- Changes in armor and weaponry are actually shown on the sprites, which makes equipping new gear feel much better.
- The Teamwork function is pretty neat. It allows for some pretty interesting tactics in combat. Having one character toss another character in order to move them closer to an enemy is a cool way to move around the map. I just wish it was more fledged out. I feel like this would be a great feature if it was just developed a bit more.

Cons

- The game is very easy. I'm playing on the hardest difficulty and I'm having no trouble so far.
- Customization feels pointless. It doesn't matter what you call your crew, your show, your attack names, etc. It's just there for the sake of having it as a selling point.
- The writing is terrible. It actually has smileys - :) - written in speech bubbles. As though the characters are somehow able to pronounce :)". Furthermore
date: not an hour in and the game blatantly tries to push an agenda down your throat by (poorly) criticizing the "damsel in distress" trope. A character mentions that his sister would like to appear on the show in respone to them needing someone to play the role of hostage
recommended: which another character immediately says they cannot allow
hoursPlayed: and they find a male person to play the role of hostage instead. It's never explained WHY having a woman in that role would be bad
voteText: they just say it's bad.\n- You cannot influence the episodes in any way. How you take out enemies
helpfulPercent: how many of your crew members go down in battle
votesHelpful: how long it takes
votesTotal: etc... All of that only influences how many fans your show gets
votesFunny: and it's all completely arbitrary. (A hero falling in battle for any reason will cause you to lose viewers
commentsCount: while something as simple as moving a hero around on the map can cause you to gain viewers.)\n- Mecha battles are insultingly simple. You have the option to either attack or defend. You can attack as many times as you want
column16: but your chance to hit decreases with each succesful strike. Defending ends your turn and gives you a bonus to defense
column17: which increases the more times you've hit your opponent this turn. On your opponent's turn
column18: you just click the mouse button at the right time to reduce damage. Eventually
column19: you gain access to a finishin move
column20: which deals high damage and ends your turn instantly. That's all.\n\nI came into this expecting something like Agarest mixed with Game Maker Tycoon. I have to say
column21: I'm very disappointed. Even if you're a huge fan of Sentai shows
column22: I imagine the cringy dialogue
column23: boring story
column24: and shallow gameplay will start to rub you the wrong way eventually.\nI cannot recommend this game to anyone
column25: and it is certainly not worth the asking price. I doubt I'll ever finish the game
column26: so I don't even consider it worth my time."

reviewText:
More reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

My goodness… does anyone remember when the Chroma Squad Kickstarter happened? There there was the whole mess with release dates and stuff? Yeh? No? Well I don’t. I just heard about Chroma Squad a few days ago. This game is proof that there is just too many cool game concepts out that, while I may not have time for them all, are way too under my radar. I’m now realizing why indie developers always link other Kickstarters in their emails.

Chroma Squad is a tactics game based on the concept of the Power Rangers’ show. The literal making of a Power Rangers’ show. Chroma Squad, at its heart, is a TV show simulation game. You start out as the five stunt-people (of your choosing from default characters and Kickstarter backer-based characters) that get tired of taking orders and decide to start their own show. You make your way into one of the stunt-person’s uncle’s warehouse (in my case “The Fro”) and find that it has a giant-floating-spikey brain in a jar (which isn’t creepy in the least) and decide to use it as their own personal Zordon.

Now it was listed in the video for Chroma Squad that you’ll get a better reviews for the episodes you record with better and flashier moves you’ll do during the show, but I wasn’t totally convinced of this until I just went around one-hitting the baddies in the second episode. (Let’s just say the tweets were bad for that one.) This part is right up my alley because my favorite moves and/or characters are usually the ones with the flashiest move sets because I am a visually stimulated person and things look cooler with explosions! That’s where teamwork comes in. If you set one of your people to be in the “Teamwork” mode and another Chroma warrior attacks, the ones waiting in that mode will join in for extra damage and a bonus to viewers added. The more surrounding a bad guy, the more damage you’ll do. If all of your buds are waiting around the same bad guy and you’ve put on your Chromatic suits you’ll do a super-special Chromatic finishing move complete with a catchphrase, light beams and power stances… good stuff all around!

It gets even deeper when you start crafting with drops from the level. Upgrades to your armor and your eventual mech are all done with common items like DuctTape, leather and cardboard boxes. I recently upgraded my mech with a cardboard box and silver duct tape and that just made me laugh. I have to admit that playing five stunt people who started their own studio and are making ends meet and working with what they’ve got is pretty stinking interesting and also kind of cool.

Score: Gewd.

Chroma Squad is a solid title. It’s good as a tactics game, but excellent as a parody of the making of a Power Rangers show. The option to upgrade your armor, weapons and mech with common items like play-do and cardboard is hilarious and fun. It definitely sets itself apart from most RPGs in that aspect, but still it’s an RPG. There is humor and humor based on nostalgia and I enjoyed both! However, at its core it’s a TV show simulation and so it all comes down to money and fans attained by the end of each episode. Maybe it gets a little easier at the end game with more things to defeat or something, but the same issue bothers me now. Since you obviously want the most viewers and money, I find myself dragging fights out to complete achievements/goals and to max out that bar. Is it necessary? Probably not too much, but it also feels like it is. Maybe it easier for some, but that meter is not my friend at times. On another note, that may not bother me as much as it does here if I could take this game with me on the go… say on my Nintendo 3DS? That would be pretty sick! Pick-up-&-play may have been better for this game for me.

reviewText:
Chroma Squad
There is alot going on with Chroma Squad but I'll keep it short...some areas of the game are very very very good...and some awful.
Let's start off with the good, Chroma Squad is a hybrid between simulation and turn based strategy. It sounds complicated, but they kept those two elements at the simplist form. So,  the developers pulled it off nicely.  I played on the easiest difficulty because I am atrocious at both genres, but this title kept me interested.  There are a few branching storyline choices to choose from, so that's a plus as well.

The storyline is hit or miss...so I'll try to keep the spoilers to a bare minimum. Note the word try:

If you read the description, if Chroma Squad, the player runs its own Super Sentai studio/show.  The actors who decide to start their own show are all best friends who got tired of their former show's director. So the player runs the studio, and the action(Turn based strategy) is the episode being filmed.
I wish it was that simple.  It begins to get confusing, because everyone begins breaking the 4th wall(from the show to their audience), sometimes the actors don't know if what's happening while on set is scripted or really happening, and then soon they begin to 'Morph'/Transform for real and fight real battles while its still being filmed.(In other words, the actors became real super heroes and saved the world). I sometimes got mixed up with what is real or what isn't real.  At one point, a developer comes on screen and tells the actors its all just a game and he made a glitch by mistake, is that the 5th wall being broken????
The gameplay was fantastic, and the retro style graphics were beautiful too.  I liked the idea of naming my studio and all the catch phrases, so the only thing I didn't like was the story, I pretty much hated it.  I wish it was either one or the other, either a Super Sentai game(Where I name the characters, catchphrases, customize colors/armor), or the same studio simulation/turn based strategy where it was kept JUST A TV SHOW without a confusing storyline.

6.5/10

I know alot of people love the story, and that's okay.  It just wasn't for me.

reviewText:
Chroma Squad
There is alot going on with Chroma Squad but I'll keep it short...some areas of the game are very very very good...and some awful.
Let's start off with the good, Chroma Squad is a hybrid between simulation and turn based strategy. It sounds complicated, but they kept those two elements at the simplist form. So,  the developers pulled it off nicely.  I played on the easiest difficulty because I am atrocious at both genres, but this title kept me interested.  There are a few branching storyline choices to choose from, so that's a plus as well.

The storyline is hit or miss...so I'll try to keep the spoilers to a bare minimum. Note the word try:

If you read the description, if Chroma Squad, the player runs its own Super Sentai studio/show.  The actors who decide to start their own show are all best friends who got tired of their former show's director. So the player runs the studio, and the action(Turn based strategy) is the episode being filmed.
I wish it was that simple.  It begins to get confusing, because everyone begins breaking the 4th wall(from the show to their audience), sometimes the actors don't know if what's happening while on set is scripted or really happening, and then soon they begin to 'Morph'/Transform for real and fight real battles while its still being filmed.(In other words, the actors became real super heroes and saved the world). I sometimes got mixed up with what is real or what isn't real.  At one point, a developer comes on screen and tells the actors its all just a game and he made a glitch by mistake, is that the 5th wall being broken????
The gameplay was fantastic, and the retro style graphics were beautiful too.  I liked the idea of naming my studio and all the catch phrases, so the only thing I didn't like was the story, I pretty much hated it.  I wish it was either one or the other, either a Super Sentai game(Where I name the characters, catchphrases, customize colors/armor), or the same studio simulation/turn based strategy where it was kept JUST A TV SHOW without a confusing storyline.

6.5/10

I know alot of people love the story, and that's okay.  It just wasn't for me.

reviewText:
Go Go Po... Chroma Rangers!

If you grew up, like me, watching the Power Rangers or any Japanese Super Sentai, it's probably worth a look.

The game use a nice pixel artstyle with a lot of color... lot of chroma!
As far as I know, it's the first Super Sentai Simulator and the two years wait since the kickstarter was worth it.
There is a story to follow so it's not a sim per say but you have some freedom with the customization of your squad and studio.

The game fit perfectly in the Super Sentai genre with crazy weird monsters, lots of weird poses and a good amount of friendships and conflicts. There is also some references to other games or memes that can be hit or miss but most of the game is spent in battle or getting ready to battle in the studio. Only a few story scenes are long, most are short unless they are important to the main plot.

The Teamwork mechanic is interesting and add a good amount of strategies to the tactical gameplay. On the normal difficulty, you can go all in like the Rangers usual do and barely win or take your time and overwhelm the baddies. Only as few battle may force you to pick a more specific strategy.

My first playthrough took me about 14 hours on the normal difficulty and, at this time, there are 3 different endings with a few different stages depending on the path taken. Except a few specific choices, the game is linear.

Oh and there are Mecha/Kaiju battles! They are pretty simple but you can't have Super Sentai without monsters growing with those slow battles full of sparks!

This review was inspired by Chroma Squad that was inspired by Saban's Power Rangers that was inspired by Toei and Bandai's Super Sentai Series.

reviewText:
After 20 hours of play I would most deffinetly that if you want to get this game...wait for a steam sale or humble bundle sale, etc. It's not worth the full asking price. The awesome atmosphere of 90s Power Rangers, Voltron and Silver Rider and the Star Sherifs is more or less lost among the repetitive grind of the game. The missions devolve into mindless running around and doing the same 4 skills on each of your squad mates over and over again, on bland, unispired, baren fields. No variaty, no interesting locations, no obsticles.

The mecha fights are a joke. You like to grind press a quick-time eventbutton 20 times, while waiting or a randomly generated percentage attack to hit or miss ? Well this is the game for you. To add insult to injury in the middle of the game there is an episode which is just mecha battles one after the other, like the developers just gave up and said ♥♥♥♥ it...

The final stage/episode is even worse. Oh do you want to fight all the bosses up until now all at once ? How about after that try to escape from a room filled with gas, while you get pummeled by a repetitive bad guys? And then get to the final boss that just spams those god damn unskippable attacks so you can watch them ...hmm 50+ times? Best day ever.

All in all - good story, cool idea, fun concept with the companies, the studio upgrades, etc.
Horrble repetitive main game - fight 5 different enemies the whole game.... - a squirel guy, a bird guy, a toad guy, a rhino guy, a possum guy....that's it - and of course the pallet swaps...

A quirky concept a good game does not make! There should be some fun gameplay somewhere in the whole mess.

reviewText:
I got this game through Humble Monthly. What that means is I didn't go out special to find it and buy it.
I hated the Power Rangers. I really and truly did. To this very day they make me cringe. I'm not sophisicated by any means; but I enjoy being entertained like the next person does; and watching robots continue to fake explode for like three minutes at a time simple isn't my cup of tea. The Power Rangers are so fake, so chinsy, and generally awful.

But if you make a game about dudes aspiring to be them with an 8-bit art style and tight controls; what you get, is an enjoyable experience.

I like to imagine this is what the team behind Power Rangers had to actually go and do. Like, at one point, they all were just wearing rain boots and could craft plastic and stuff together to make a spiffy top hat; and then they all did shots of vodka and did an episode.

Its got a crafting system that'll allow you to make better weapons and costume parts; thus improving your stats and killing the dudes faster and easier.

This game also takes a few pages out of recent Fire Emblem game's playbook in a good way and will let you use teamwork to get farther ahead in the map; or you can use them to pummel foes. Its just a bit annoying having to constantly tell them to use teamwork; and it  can ony be used once per turn. Also the game is kinda like a game of chess where you can move all your dudes and attack maybe in one turn; which again; takes me back to FE. I know FE isn't the only game that does this; but its the only one I can think of.


The Story is basiclly what you'd expect; its not lack-luster but its not awful; the battle system isn't creative but its also not overused and they do it well. They give you objectives that can provide bonus' if completed; and you gotta complete them. Cuz if you don't you'll just run out of money.

You can change actors for certain benefits if you want, it tries to be funny and doesn't succeed for me, everything you buy will take money from you after you buy it which I feel is quite needless; why not just let us have the buff.

So.
Is it fun? Yes.
Should you get it? On sale, yes.
Will I beat it? Eventually.
Rating: 7/10

reviewText:
Well that was a good game, but not all that long, on casual if you don't muck up, about a dozen hours. I just finished it as I type this review, their were very few things ultimately that bugged me however, nothing really that bad that I'd give it a negative recommendation, but still it bugged me.

First you don't have one of each pieces of armor and each weapons at 'Legendary' quality, you got a pistol & a sword, I guess so those can be wielded by everyone however if you got used to wield class specific weapons its a let down that you can't have a unique Legendary weapon for each classes, also while you got one armor and two helmets for your characers armor, I found it lacking that you couldn't have boots and make a full Legendary armor, which would have been nice for the finale, but from what I seen you can't sadly, it would have been really a great idea for the very last mission at least to be able to have all your team in full Legendary.

Next is New Game +, I saw the narrator after the credits mention that, it would have been great to finish your game on a level than be able to New Game + to the next difficulty level. Now the game has been out for a few months and still no  sign of that sadly. If not for a New Game + one thing that would have been great would have been to be able to replay any mission after the end or after having done them, so that you could fight again any battles, sure their might not be able to alter the storyline path you took, but just replaying the missions would have been a pretty good idea, give the game a bit more longevity. Right now the game feel limited in what you can do, since ou can't continue into a New Game + with your stuff or you can't continue in that game either , when its over its over, whatever you like it or not. I did see their is a mention of some sort of 'Episode Editor' program that would allow us to create custom episodes for endless gaming, I can't wait for it to come out.

Otherwise maybe the selection of potential characters is a bit limited too, I went for a all female team and I was just able to do it, you have barely enough characters of each genders to fill in a full team, without accounting I think for the backers special characters which are... peculiar... one is an weird animal thing, one is a robot, another looked like a lazy bum, and the last is some guy with a shop discount.... but it would have been nice to have a few more picks, if I want to play a new all female team I'd be forced to go with the exact same team and the only way to change things up would be to shift whom is what... so yea, a bit lacking on that part.

Still when all is said and done, this game is great, it was worthwhile for me to get it and I hope it will be expanded upon, maybe get a sequel in time, since the scene at the very end imply their could be a sequel to it, I really want it to be true, hopefully one that would correct the few issues and build up to a even greater game, but that is something we'll have to wait and see about, I really wish for it to happen, if not at least another Tactical RPG of that quality would always be welcome.

reviewText: Just beat this game last night (got the Tammy story line) and for what it was worth I thought it was a solid game. I feel as though that if you're a huge fan of Power Rangers or the Sentai genre or a big fan of RPG games, this game is for you. It has a lot of references to Sentai shows like Power Rangers and even other super hero based things like Marvel and DC to random things like Little Mermaid and Barney the dinosaur. This helps it to an extent because after a while the references were getting kind of old and repeptitive. Also on some levels the number of enemies on the field at a time is crazy and I feel as though that the game kept making more and just had a bunch in the corner standing around till more died. It was kind of annoying in that regard to especially when you would have a supposedly strong boss, only to have him being shielded by tons of minions. Still though I thought this game was fun and the sound track as well as look were kick ♥♥♥ and I will be playing this through again at some point, and try and get a different story line. If you're a fan of power rangers, sentai shows, or rpgs, I totally suggest this game!

Its got a crafting system that'll allow you to make better weapons and costume parts; thus improving your stats and killing the dudes faster and easier.

reviewText:
I was interested by the premise of a power rangers-esque tactical RPG, but this game had everything it promised and more!

The best part of this game is the fun and satisfying gameplay. The tactics you implement in fights like the team acrobatics and team attacks are true to both this genre of game and the TV shows Chroma Squad draws inspiration from. There's so many different play styles you can try thanks to the no-penalty selection of skills. By no-penalty I mean that if you want to change a character's skills alter their strengths and weaknesses you can do total 180s. The freedom to experiment with different strategies really add a lot of replay value to this game.

The crafting is very thought out with different tiers organized so that there are no useless crafting items and none of them are too hard to get. The studio upgrades, mecha upgrade, shop, and agency stuff are all great inclusions that all players to go wild with improving and powering up their characters. I also love being able to make my own power rangers  including their names, colours, catch phrases, and all that other cool super hero stuff.

The visuals are pixelly, but in a good way. Behold Studios did a great job using an old-school graphics style in a cinematic and modern way. Even though everything is a clearly made from little squares, there is detail involving perspective, lighting, and various other aspects that gives this 2D world a bigger feeling. This style is similar to games like Hotline Miami and Party Hard, if you need an example.

The music is awesome, once again capturing the vibe of those 90's shows we all remember so fondly, but being modern and pleasing to the ear. The theme songs for specific characters are all tailored quite well to who they are paired with. The story at first made me think meh"
date: but after a couple episodes I was drawn into being a squad of stuntmen trying to make their way in the world independently of The Man. And even more drawn in when the stakes get raised and the stuntmen squad must become genuine heros.\n\nThere are minor quirks here or there
recommended:
but none worth mentioning since they've probably already been fixed as I'm typing this.


TL;DR: if you like incrediby well made tactical RPGs and have a nostalgia scratch to itch
hoursPlayed: then you should really play this game."

reviewText: In a review that requires no analysis whatsoever, all you need to really know about Chroma Squad is that it feels and plays exactly like a reverent burst of childhood nostalgia. Centered around a Power Rangers motif and tactical role playing gameplay, it's a concept that is never taken too seriously and instead commits to delivering an experience both entertaining and unabashedly ridiculous. The developers clearly used an endearing sheaf of letters to spell its love for the sentai genre and consequently you'll be hard tasked to find a game executed with more fun and heart than Chroma Squad. An essential addition for anyone who wants to embrace the pure joy of video gaming.

reviewText:
What I found was something in between a tycoon style game, like Game Dev Tycoon and a 8 bit top-down tactical RPG.  Hmm.  So does the concept work?
Growing up I liked power rangers - it was such a cool show.  As I grew older I really liked RPG games on my Gameboy Color.  Pokemon Yellow, Zelda, and then on our home PC FFVII.  So when I saw this game, I thought I would really enjoy it.  But it just failed to catch my attention, I never felt engaged or interested in what was happening in game.

Pros
The theme is great.  You are making “power ranger” episodes and gaining more viewers/money depending on how well you perform.
The genre is unique.  As I said, somewhere between a tactical RPG and a business sim game.  Very unique, and indeed a good idea.
I think the 8-bit style (or is it 16?) is appropriate as the game is a throwback to the ‘90s.Cons
Ultimately, I just couldn’t get into the gameplay, progression, or the story.
THe only real technical complain I have is that I found the interface odd and uneasy.  Sometimes it's difficult to tell, according to the character selection bar on the right, which avatar correlates to various characters on the map.  Setting up the vital teamwork moves is also a little awkward and inconsistent

reviewText:
Key given by the developer for review purposes only,no other compensation is received.

OVERVIEW
In Chroma Squad you control a group of actors that make a super sentai show, with a mad and boring director.Until one day they resolve to create his own show to get success.You will start with a simple and old basement gived to you by the uncle of a team member.you will grow your studio getting new upgrades,recording new episodes,getting fans and managing contracts by mail system from the game.The gameplay is turn-rpg based where each team has a turn to move and attack,you also get a team work special named chromatize,where your actors transform in super sentai ones. Your goal here is to grow and not lose fans,because if the fans number reach 0,you will lose the entire game.
-----------------------------------
PROS & CONS

Pros:
Unique gameplay style,make your own way,no equal quests.
You change the order of episodes to play.
Really Small,and most of the machines can handle it.
Extremely addictive,many achievements and a couple of hours to beat the game.
Also game features many languages to choose,making it for all.

Cons:
If you play without pausing times,can be repetitive.
-----------------------------------

SUMMARY & FINAL RATING
A game for people that ever dreamed making your super sentai show.Inumerous hours of gameplay,much content,and such features makes this game unique and awesome,also game is really cheap and you can grab it with a big discount on sale also.

reviewText:
Play this game if you a) really like tactical RPGs, or b) are really nostalgic for Sentai shows.

The mecha battle system is really poorly designed—that's what ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off enough to stop playing the game. But if I liked the rest of the game MORE, I'd probably stick with it. Also, don't play this game if you get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off by attacks missing due to invisible probibilities and die rolls.

I really wish I liked this game enough to play it to completion, but I a) don't like it enough, b) had reached the end of my patience with the mecha battles. It has a really cool crafting system and some other neat mechanics, and I find the combat really satisfying when I feel like I'm using the acrobatics and teamwork to good effect. But it's just not doing it for me. I'd still reccomend it, though (to people who like tactical RPGs or Power Rangers).

reviewText:
As other reviews have pointed out, I think you really have to like the very specific references and story content to fall in love with this. It caters to a very specific market, that unfortunately, is just not my cup of tea.

All I can really comment on is the actual game. For some reason, the complexity and depth reminded me of Advanced Wars in the sense that it is fairly shallow and lite compared to other much deeper turn-based fighting games. Its not bad - it is just a certain kind of thing. I like the base management, but others have said that choices don't matter all that much. I did like the art style, but it wasn't enough to carry me further.

If you watch the trailer and it screams 'play me!', then this is *probably* for you. I bought it based off of the 'overwhelmingly positive' review status. Bad idea - I actually got a refund since it was fifteen bucks. Obviously there is a fan base, but I am not a part of it.
