reviewText:
TL;DRToo ♥♥♥♥ing bad, read the damn review. If you're on this game's page you surely don't have anything better to do.

Chroma Squad?Chroma Squad? I’m not too sure what that means, I’m pretty sure the devs thought that Google Chrome was kind of cool and decided to name their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game after it. So yes, two sentences into this review and you know my stance on this game. Indeed, this means I can spend the rest of the review flaming up a storm -- after I go over what the game is, and what is good.

Chroma Squad is a game that attempts to combine crafting because all the cool games have crafting so why wouldn’t we, with elements from Game Dev Story, then they stapled a turn-based combat system on to that formula to make sure they would attract all the niches to their doorstep on Halloween, only for the youngsters to find out that this guy only gives out single mini-twizzler packs despite all the hype. So what is the game about? Well, more or less you’re a group of people who are stunt acting for *generic movie studio* in a show that is more or less Power Rangers,  and then you and your squad of ♥♥♥♥ bois who share striking resemblance to the Power Rangers decide to make their own movie studio. I kind of want to make a movie studio now too. You show up in your uncles warehouse to film, without his consent, but then when he talks to you, you realize that this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is Bob Marley levels of chill. He didn’t give a single ♥♥♥♥ that we just stormed into his warehouse to film our Power Rangers rule 34. You then must shoot episodes and manage your “company.” Shooting episodes is where the turn based combat they stole directly from the Shadowrun series comes into play.

What is good?So what is good about this steaming pile of over-hyped garbage that somehow made it into my Humble Monthly bundle? Well, the management part is okay; and by okay I mean better than getting shot in the knee caps with a .44 -- which doesn’t set the bar too high. It’s cool at first, you get to choose advertising companies, equip your group of under-qualified ♥♥♥♥s, and even change the different sayings in the game. When in combat, your group says some stuff during certain points like when turning into their actual “Chroma” form. I, of course, took full advantage off this opportunity, making the whole game look like it was written by that 9 year old on CoD who just learned the word “♥♥♥♥♥♥” and has too many red bulls on hand as well as a mother who just doesn’t give a damn. The management gets stale quick considering nothing changes. Every couple of missions they just append more items and companies making full use of the random number generator. You can craft fun stuff for your team, but crafting materials is gathered by killing in the field, and no. Just buy your ♥♥♥♥.

And for the bad.So, now that we’ve gone over the good, let’s start the real flaming. Let’s start with the most obvious thing, Chroma Squad looks like the kind of pixel art you find 90s kids making on MS Paint in Windows XP, minus originality and artistic vision. But on top of the pixel art just being straight up trash, it’s scaled all to hell. When you have a pixel art game, you make sure the display is pixel perfect, because when you scale it like in Chroma Squad, it looks like someone took each image in Gimp, scaled it down to 100*100 then back to 1366*76; my native resolution. But it doesn’t stop there. The game tempts you with good graphics. They throw on a hard-core CRT shader, because all Unity games need their “CUSTOM SHADER,” and the graphics become tolerable. The shader is equivalent to going into Hammerwatch, and switching on all the options that ♥♥♥♥ your GPU. But nope, it only lasts for seconds at a time, so pipe dream.

Now that I’ve got that off my chest, let’s talk about combat. As I stated before, the combat is a Shadowrun rip-off for pixel games. They basically found a free Unity game decompiler and run Shadowrun Returns through it, stole the combat code, and placed it in their game. Yet, someone on the team didn’t get the memo, and stole all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ parts out of Shadowrun and Banner Saga instead, and then replaced the rest with his poorly-done excuse of a script. So we are left with a combat system that is so unstable you’d think it’s your grandpa’s black-market dialysis machine. For starters, the best way to do turn based combat is one person from one team gets a turn, then the other team gets a turn, and so on. But not in this game. You see, the game gets its difficulty from pressing an enemy, hitting Ctrl + C, then holding down Ctrl + V for a solid ten seconds until the screen is so full of random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, you’d think Harper was on the TV. So this means all of the enemies get their turn at once, and will completely ♥♥♥♥ your entire team worse than America rapes resource-filled countries then slap a “terrorists” sticker on it all the while spewing out ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t reasons as to why they shouldn’t lose their guns. Once your team has taken more hits than a rich heroin junkie, you can “Chromatize” and turn in to your stronger form and use the weapons you bought. You can use your weapons like once every 5 turns, even if you’re packing a 9, because apparently it takes the equivalent of waiting at the DMV to reload a magazine-fed semi-automatic weapon. Okay. Other than that, you can jump over other teammates, do team attacks, and help a brother out. You can then use a generic finisher on the boss at the end to gain some audience or some fans or some ♥♥♥♥; I don’t ♥♥♥♥ing know anymore.

Sometimes after you’ve finished off the boss, you are welcomed to a giant mecha fight versus the very boss you just beat that is now somehow the size as Trump’s tower combined with his ego. These fights are worse than watching cement set. At least with cement some dumb ♥♥♥  might step in it then you can get all pissy at them and tell them about all the hard work it will take to fix it before doing nothing about it. With this garbage mini game you can hit the enemy, special hit the enemy, defend against the enemy, and special defend against the enemy. My favorite part is that the enemy has about three times more health than you and doesn’t miss. So lots of rage will be had. But fret not! If you run out of health you can use “Fan power!” You get some health and finish the job basically giving zero required skill to win. So that’s fun.

What else is on my list to smear ♥♥♥♥ from the Taco Bell bathroom on is there still left? Oh yeah, the cut scenes. If they were bad, I would just call them cancer and move on, but this is much worse. The game is “a tv series” so you have to know what’s going on in every episode. The writer constantly breaks the fourth wall between the audience of your show and the show itself, for no reason other than “it was cool when MGS 2 did it.” You can hold down enter to try and skip, but it still takes like thirty seconds to get through it, while staring at yet another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ shader they included because why the hell not. It’s not even just that. The writing is more cringe-worthy than The Room’s sex scenes.

ConclusionI think I’ve used all the ♥♥♥♥ out of the Taco Bell bathrooms now, so time to wrap it up. The game was made by hipsters on Mac Book Pros in Starbucks leeching off the free WiFi because they’re on a Ramen Noodle every night kind of budget, working in Unity to create the “latest and greatest” pixel Unity game. It’s trash, it’s three different game concepts glued together with 10 year old epoxy from the shed, and I’d like to know how this first year University project made it on to my damned monthly bundle I paid 15 Canadian bucks for. Now that I have offended almost every niche in the first world, to the rest still reading, congratulations.

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of Tactical RPGs and I'm a big fan of SNES-era graphics, so this is why I bought this game.

While downloading I was reading up on the company and was happily surprised to see that they also made Table-Top RPG (or something like that) which I also enjoyed a lot.

To sum it up, the game is fun and challenging but gets repetitive quickly. I tried it on hard from the start and after 1 hour restarted on Medium to get the hang of the game more (it WAS hard, my heroes kept dying and I couldn't finish any extra goals).

The combat is fun and you get new skills often enough that you don't get bored.

However, I think I am at about 60% of the game so far and it has started to become quite repetitive for me. There are very few different enemy units, the story is not that interesting, and the Giant Robot Battles lose their charm after the 2nd one - it's always exactly the same.

I haven't had any real trouble with the fights for a little while now, but the extra 2 goals they give you during missions are not always easy to complete, so it gives a nice twist.

I'm now slowly playing it when I have free time (I'm also a CIV V addict) just to say I finished it, but after 8 hours, I was bored.

Wait for a discount.

On another note, I'm now watching Sentai again.

reviewText: This game could have been good in a lot of respects. The idea was novel, but after that was over the game you were left with was poor in many respects. You can not skip cutscene and the characters, abilities, and roles are all very static with little to no customization possible. The only choices you can make have clear right and wrong options with very little balance. This is all on top of cringe worthy dialog that drags on, including preachy speeches about sexism. And you have to sit through all of it because lets not forget, you can't skip cutscenes. Despite how little it appears that I've played this game I have actually logged many hours on another account encompassing mech fights, crafting, and character choices (when available).

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. There's some really good ideas and bit and pieces that work well together, but then the game quickly remembers it's an indie title so it immediately breaks the fourth wall with some dumb meme joke and poorly placed rants about sexism. It wouldn't have been so bad had the dialogue actually followed what sentai/powerranger shows were like, but it isn't ; it's completely about these random, pre-made characters that always spew the same lines regardless of their gender/race/species. Why even let people choose the visual appearance of them if you've already created characters for them? It would have been better just to create a premade team that apes the original show's archetypes rather than blandly change the visuals.

The game also suffers in that there's too much fluff and not enough depth. You have weapons, crafting, a store and various upgrades - but they all feel meaningless. Nothing really excels and feels like it was tacked on because all rpgs must have crafting now, rather than it was something important to the game play.

Lastly, the art can be downright confusing or poorly imitating at times. For some reason my blonde female support character won't stop rubbing her nipples in her idle animation. It's kind of disturbing and is weirding me out. Just, standing there all day, rubbing away. Did nobody notice this ????

reviewText:
I'm sorry to say that I wasn't a fan, and I wanted to post some of my issues to other prospective buyers. I'd like to clarify that I'm a big fan of both management/sim games, SRPGs and Sentai, so I fall right into the game's key demographic.

The game is spoiled by poor writing throughout the gameplay experience - I understand the developers are working against a language barrier, but this means that much of the dialogue has no flow or substance. Tonally, the dialogue never seems whether to indulge in the action fantasy of sentai, or provide a narrative about the stunt crew pursuing their own career. The result is that the characters are constantly breaking the fourth wall which is not only tiresome, but spoils the atmosphere the game's (very good) graphics are depicting.

The game has been designed without level ups: where this might seem beneficial to some, they've replaced this tried and tested mechanism with a bolted-on crafting system. You become dependent on crafting gear from items dropped by enemies - worse, you have to hope that the 'random bonus' is actually worth having. The removal of level ups takes away a sense of stable progression, and replaces it with gear-dependence, which, for me, sucks the fun out of the game.

The management aspect is not developed or interesting enough as a worthwhile distraction, and the two gameplay modes (simulation/SRPG) don't mesh with each other in a satisfactory way. The lack of depth in the simulation and the lack of levelling are disempowering - you're never sure where you sit on the game's difficulty curve, and ultimately your successes do not feel like they've originated from any choices you've made. This is poisonous for any game, but Chroma Squad simply fails to provide any grit, depth or detail beyond what is an impressive exterior.

TL;DR: It looks great on the surface, but goes to pieces once you get past the unique premises, references, and graphics.

reviewText:
General Review:

The game is cool, but has too much dialog. The storyline is so gigantic they even added a fast forward feature that came in handy when the game crashed and I had to restart a level. Pros:

-Based on Sentai shows
-Studio options are very diverse
-Turn based combat system
-Nice 8bit feeling
-The game is full of intelligent humor
-Game has a lot of references

Cons:

-TOO MANY bugs and unexpected crashes
-Crafting things is a messy task because some items have random status
-The recycling feature is useless cause drop rates are fu*ked up (for real)
-The giant robot fights are too flat, I dare to say boring

reviewText: Great soundtrack, terrible game. Chroma Squad fails on all fronts, it's lackluster as an SRPG and it's tycoon elements are few and far between. The writing is abysmal and does little to pay real homage to the brand of Japanese TV shows it's emulating (I wonder if the writers have ever actually seen an episode of Super Sentai) it's full of internet memes that serve no real purpose and just comes off as lazy overall. The backer content is also predictably awful, I wish kickstarters would cease this trend of letting their backers insert anything at all into their games.\n\nAvoid this one, even if you're a fan of Sentai shows, unfortunately that's the hook that lured me in and the end results leave me feeling very disappointed.

reviewText:
TL;DR 2: The -- just gonna go out on a limb and realize I've been a lil harsh.

Its colourful, if you're super bored and its 4 am then who's to realize you're a dank memer and you just love shity ♥♥♥♥ing memes that would make Pepe proud (only god and your mother who will both send you to hell damn you.). Its one of those things where you're very easily amused by grinds and futile mechanics things will work for you, or if you thrive in the badness of things. Like naming your squad the Peepee patroller and naming your mech the WOBBLY SAUSAGE, caps mandatory. Its stupid, really stupid, not really lucid gameplay sort of fun, play it if you're tired, bored, and its priced at the fiveish dollars its worth. Man, it's 4 am RIGHT NOW AS I'M TYPING IT, I'm exhausted and my friends are asleep  after a night of enjoyment, I'm actually having fun while gorging myself on brownie bars. Still not reccomended, but, eh, if you're a sad little man and you know it, buy Chroma rangers, cue jingle I'm outies.

TL;DR: Power Rangers (but not really, its more a side detail to people cracking dank memes), dull mecha maymays, some people are mad about Social Justice, but the game itself just isn't as thrilling as it promises to be. RIP in Pepperoni.

Not really as great as its touted to be. It seems for half a second it would be tactically challenging but then you realize everything you fight is just an issue of placement, which at times could be avoided if you were allowed to pick your path rather than autorouting. The item system relies a little too much on you getting lucky, and only really serves to make you irritated wih things. Squad customizations are funny for a while but you really get tired of what you see soon, and its a bit annoying when you realize into the game you put the wrong person into the wrong role. Humour is forced. Good lord is it forced, not even mentioning the heavy handed shoehorned stupid SJW messages (which really don't make sense by the way), which, really, I understand given the market of tumblr being so easy to reel into guaranteed sales, but... the humour itself gets really worn out really fast. Audience system is mostly pointless since just running a lot and using the positioning system will top you out easy enough and it just serves to drag fights on if you're going for all of the pointless little guys. Not to mention, a lot of the skills look cool! Then don't really do anything compared to the normal punching action, combined with a lack of many real skills, its best to just stick to passives save for the one starter heal move and punch things to hell. Mecha battles are excruiatingly bland and don't really carry the oomph you're hoping for, its more of a rock paper scissors game but without any chance of losing unless you somehow hit ALT+F4.

reviewText:
Go-go SUPER LUCK SQUAD!

I'm reviewing this game purely on the gameplay aspect. There are plenty of positive reviews regarding story and sentai fanservice.

This is based on playing the highest difficulty:
This game is a decent turn-based game in it's own right. There isn't much strategy to it. A bit of planning is involved to complete the director's instructions, but in the end it all comes down to luck. The most important thing to making equipment, materials, all based on luck.

I have one save file where a certain material I obtain in abundance, and really dont need it as it's mostly for the starter equipment, and another save file where the only material I've been obtaining is the make the same pair of gloves. If you dont keep your equipment up to snuff, your rangers are as good as dead or too weak to complete director's instructions as the episodes difficulty increase.
_____

Now for the actual gameplay. Here is wear luck becomes absolutely infuriating. Let me give some examples:
Now, remember, you control a squad of 5 rangers.
The director wants you to kill all of a certain enemy within, say, 3 turns. There are about 10 enemies on the field, and you need to focus on 3 specific ones. Those specific ones need to all be dead in 3 turns. Sounds simple enough, plan out how you'll position your rangers to catch them and take them out.
Now, let's get to the problem:

- Most of the squishy enemies, unless you luckily score a critical, can't be killed by a single ranger. This means it will take two of your rangers attacking to guarantee that kill. After a ranger attacks, they're done for that turn. This means it should be no problem for you to kill 3 of the weak enemies within 3 turns. Let's not get into details about some rangers having to use up their turn just to move around and get close to these enemies. We'll just presume you'll probably be spread thin and only have a kill average of 1 enemy per turn.... wait, change that from 'kill' to 'chance to kill'. You have a 'chance' to kill 1 enemy per turn. So if you happen to miss this chance, you can kiss that director's instruction goodbye, and restart the episode. Let's type how this will play out if you're unlucky:

First turn: you manage to kill an enemy.
Second turn: you manage to kill another enemy.
Third turn, your last turn to complete the instructions, and you're only one kill away: you order your rangers to attack and... the enemy dodges. Well, you're screwed. Time to abort episode and try again.
This is how many of your games will play out. This may not be too bad when it's just the start of an episode. However, there are times when an episode has 3 parts and you can spend an hour of your time going through the episode, completing all director's instructions only to have some unlucky crap happen at the very end and have to restart from the very beginning.
That's a lot of time to be wasting over something that's completely out of your control, luck.

I'll give you one of my recent episodes as an example, there are three parts. The first two parts are simple enough, the third part involves a boss that can heal itself and many enemies around that heal. You have to kill the boss within 10 turns and finish it with a finishing move. A finishing move requires all your rangers to be next to the boss and attack together(use Teamwork).
Technically, you have to kill the boss within 9/10 turns, since he will stun your rangers(making you unable to use the finishing move on the 10th turn, as it requires all of your rangers) on specific turns... one of those specific turns being the 10th one. Now, that seems like a pretty decent time to take out the boss. That is, if you're lucky. Let's play this out:

(We'll skip the small details and say you manage to get rid of the healing minions within 3 turns. You now have 6 turns left to take out the boss, who will also heal himself for pretty hefty amount. If you're lucky, he wont heal too often. If you're unlucky, he might heal twice in a row, making all your damage done to him in a turn, null. You still should have no problems as long as you manage to keep hitting him every turn and wittle him down. Given you have proper planning, you'll be just fine!)

Turn 1/6: You manage to quadruple the boss, and dealing enough damage that will allow you to outdps his heal.
Turn 2/6: You deal enough to outdps his heal again.
Turn 3/6: He dodges, completely wasting a turn, and heals himself. That's okay, you see that you still have a chance to take him out in time.
Turn 4/6: He dodges again... okay, it might  be close, but just maybe you can make it.
Turn 5/6: He dodges again, and heals. He's now at full health again, it's game over. Time to abort and do the whole episode again, taking up another hour of your time.
_______

Let me give you one last situation. In this one, YOUR luck can be your downfall in completing instructions. Let's say you need to kill 4 enemies in a single turn. Well, remember how it can take two rangers just to kill one enemy? You have 5 rangers, it takes 2 to kill one. Simple math, you can't kill 4 in a single turn. Unless... you plan ahead and simply soften them up to kill at once later. You're so clever. A tactical genius in the making. This shouldn't be a problem, you've got the plan and the means to execute it! What could go wrong?
None of the enemies dodge, you manage to soften up 4 of them enough to where any single ranger can finish them off in your next turn. There's absolutely nothing that could go wrong. Unless... <.<

It's the enemy's turn: The weakened enemy attacks your ranger, it's super effective! At least super effective against the enemy, because your ranger decides that of all times he's going to choose this time to do a counter-attack. The softened up enemy dies. Now you only have three softened up enemies, maybe you still have a chance. You'll have 3 rangers kill the 3 softened ones, and your other 2 rangers can double attack some other enemy. Unless... <.<
It's still the enemy's turn: Another of the weakened enemies attacks another ranger. You couldn't possibly be so lucky you counter attack again, could you? I dont think I need to say where this is going. You know you're screwed, abort episode and try again.


The game could also stand to give some actual info on the stat points. There seems to be no info on the usefulness or effective amounts for Cooldown Cost and Skill Regen. There are other stats as well that have no explanation in the game, and you just have to guess and hope they're worth investing into.

If they cut out all of the luck crap, it would be an entertaining turn-based game that actually rewarded you for proper planning. Instead, it's always a roll of the dice.
I dont know how many hours Steam will say I've played this game, but my first save file is 11 hours. My second save file says 3 hours. So any beyond that was just wasted time from having to abort episodes.

reviewText:
As soon as I played it I IMMEDIATELY knew this had to be the same team behind Knights of pen and paper.

If you are buying this expecting it to have some simulation elements or have strong RPG elements then immediately stay away from this game. This development team has sucked me in many times with the premises of their games but they never follow through with this premise.

I certainly would have loved a game about making my own Sentai series where my decisions determine not only how popular the show is with the combat being real tactical battles with impressive fakey" special effects with many of its comedic moments being just the sort of crud a studio would pull to save money. Yet that isn't how the game works.

Basically to understand the game you take the role of several stunt workers who have decided to make their own "power ranger" type show. You achieve this by having random fights at which you are given goals that you must succeed
date: there is a story but the characters involved mostly speak entirely out of character at all times.\n\nIn fact that is probably my biggest gripe about the game's comedy is that it has absolutely no grounding. The game makes no attempt to even pretend like there is a show actually being recorded because characters almost never say their proper lines and cannot shut up for a moment about their own special effects or plotting. So some jokes
recommended: such as the characters not being able to transform because their costumes are in the cleaners out of show

reviewText: THIS IS AN AMAZING GAME!!!dont listen to people that say it sucks if you have the money to buy it, BUY IT!! it has an ok to good story the gameplay is awesome and the RPG touch is the cherry of the cake
This game is amazing need I say anything but game dev tycoon with power rangers!!!!

OUTSTANDING!    I still can't Decide if this is the Most awesome dumb game, or the Dumbest Awesome game that I've played in years!   It took me back to the days of the streamlined SNES games... Hilarious story, great playability, HELLA fun... with Juuust enough graphics. For all the fans, from Ultraman to Power Rangers... this game is a fan-boy nerdgasm!
Excellent, fun, and creative.

Did you (or do you) like Power Rangers?  Did you watch Power Rangers even after sprouting pubic hair?  Shameful, shameful pubic hair?  Yes?  Great.  You'll absolutely love this games.

It's tactical, the combat is fun and rewarding, the music is excellent, and the systems are deep and engaging.

Hiring actors, naming them and your studio, buying/crafting gear for you squad - all of these scrath an itch a RPG fan will likely be very familiar with and appreciated.  The premise and writing are cheesey, but that is abosolutely what the devs were going for and they nail it.

If you're a fan of FF Tactics, Fire Emblem, or any games in similar genres you will enjoy this.  If you like RPGs you will enjoy this.  If you've watched Power Rangers and loved it at some point in your life, you will love this.  Great to see something like this in gaming.  Got as a gift but will buy and gift to somebody else to support.  Great job on this one devs.

I will recommend this game to anyone is a fan of RPG who wants a fun experience without having to spend too much money but to me the game is worth more than there selling it at as a fan of Power Rangers and Super Sentai this game is one of the best times I have had with a game and will be in my top 5 games of this year. It has a interesting and complex combat which will seem simple at a first look but has a hidden complexity with the audience to impress. The game has very loose and meta humour so if that’s not your thing the story may be confusing and annoying.

If there any negatives in my opinion is that you cannot customize the characters and Mecha much. The mecha battle don't add to the audience bar. The update crafting system is improved from the earlier versions but ends up being more difficult to use and I found myself using the store. The final problem is that every time you start a new camping you have to go through the tutorial and due to this makes the beginning of the game a grind.

Even with these problems I love this game and its really worth a go and I am going to end buying it again for Playstation 4 but if you don't feel like buying I am betting on it being a Playstation Plus game or a least small discount even if in my case I feel the game is cheap all ready.
A neat game for Power Rangers and sentai fans. As a strategy rpg, the mechanics are simple but the game is still wildly entertaining!

WOW.

I just finished Chroma Squad and I loved it. I am gonna explain with a couple of keywords what kind of game this is (for those who are considering to buy Chroma Squad):

- Tactical RPG, the tactical form in this game is centered in how you skill your characters (more than positioning).
- Mech fights, YES MECHS.
- Game time, I completed the game in 20 hours.
- Difficulties, there is easy, interesting and challenging. Hardest difficulty is a real ♥♥♥♥♥!
- Managing, beside the tactical RPG side of the game, you need to manage your characters by crafting, teching their skills, upgrading your mech, marketing, responding to e-mail where choices matter (not heavily), upgrading your studio and buying items.
- Achievements, well done compared to most indie games.
- Comedy & awesomeness, this game gave me laughs and goosebumps. Comedy is based on parodies of modern memes, Power Rangers and other silly stuff. I got goosebumps in the final fight, where I just got blown away by the story and momentum of it.
- Story is well done and original.

TL:DR
Chroma squad is an original indie game which has two sides of gameplay: tactical RPG and managing your party. The story is wel done and takes around 15+ hours to complete. I had ALOT OF FUN completing this game and I am happy I bought it. You need to understand the mechanics, but the moment you do its fun as hell.

P.S. Don't craft anything until the later seasons, buying items is the way to go.

A creative tribute to the Tokusatsu genre that many have grown up to or still enjoy. Having team work and acrobatics effect audience levels was an interesting mechanic that allowed to the player to decide on how much of either to do to maximize the attendance to gain more fans/money per episode. The attendance machanic in general seemed a bit easy to abuse to an extent, should have a negative factor if either is overly used.

Having different characters to choose from at the beginning for each role is a really nice touch. It allowed to add in variety to characters with the abilities that affected the gameplay. This allows the player to choose how they would like to play their games, and not have a stagnant gameplay with fixed characters for the storyline only.

Storyline progressed at a decent pace and was well thought out in respect to what Tokusatsu's usually revolved around. But also adding in a bit of flare by blurring reality with fiction.

One thing that was unimpressive after a few levels would be the minion's designs. During a level that had a Boss Mob, could have had the minion's designs centered around that particular Boss in the later stages. It's understandable at the beginning since it is representing the beginning stages of a starter company.
Fun game, Xcom light + Power Rangers

Im giving this a positive review because it has deserved it.
The only reason you should not buy this game is if you absolutely HATE tactical RPGs.
Otherwise get it.
+Fluid and well done Pixel Art
+FANTASTIC Music
+Fun and simple tactical combat. But not easy peasy if you let your guard down!
+Enjoyable if somewhat predictable story that, if you dont take it too seriously, is a great experience all the way. Plenty of 4th wall breaking too
+Massive quantity of customization. From outfit colours, to the actors inside the suits, to the effing Catchphrases to transform and the one to call your Mecha.
+Lots of items to craft and buy to outfit your characters and give them different attributes. RPG veterans will spend quite a while in the room outfitting


-You won't get too many abilities in this game overall for your actors. And the classes are set. Just a little thing that might just be me nitpicking.
-If you fail an Episode, or decide to restart it, getting to the point you were at, skipping all the text is a bit tedious. I did feel like I was being punished for restarting the mission, instead of going through and failing it and taking a hit in my fanbase. But its the same for failing.
-A few hilarious but present Graphical glitches, which luckily did not harm my gameplay. The most common one for me were my actors greeting clone version of themselves in the studio interface.

LIGHTS,CAMERA,CHROMATIZE!

I bought this game on a whim, and I don't regret it.  I really enjoyed the fast paced combat, the crafting, and studio upgrade system.  I thought I'd have an issue that the squad really only levels up through gear you equip, but it didn't actually bother me that much.  You get a new ability every season, so that in its own, felt kind of like progression.

I didn't care for the mecha fights so much, it was cool at first, but got boring fast.

I played on the hardest difficulty, having little experience in Tactical RPGs, but I ended up have only a few issues until the final boss, where the difficulty amped up big time.

If you like fast paced Tactical RPG's, you'll like this.

It's really fun, and the music's nice. The graphics could be a little better, even for sprites, but they're still charming. I feel like the creator/creators are subtley pushing their opinions/ideals through the game, and it's a turn off. But, the game's fun enough to let me ignore it.
Fantastic game, highly addictive. You can tell a lot of time and thought was put into thos game, worthy of the money. Cannot belive I didn't buy this sooner! Highly reccomend.

My biggest problem is when the game changes from the TV view to normal view when you load your game or start a episode. It gives me a really bad migraine after a some time, but that's my only really problem with the game.
Great gameplay, awesome characters, catchy soundtrack and witty game dialogue.\n\nWhat more can i say.. 10/10 BEST GAME OF THE YEAR!

Did you (or do you) like Power Rangers?  Did you watch Power Rangers even after sprouting pubic hair?  Shameful, shameful pubic hair?  Yes?  Great.  You'll absolutely love this games.

It's tactical, the combat is fun and rewarding, the music is excellent, and the systems are deep and engaging.

Hiring actors, naming them and your studio, buying/crafting gear for you squad - all of these scrath an itch a RPG fan will likely be very familiar with and appreciated.  The premise and writing are cheesey, but that is abosolutely what the devs were going for and they nail it.

If you've watched Power Rangers and loved it at some point in your life, you will love this.  Great to see something like this in gaming.  Got as a gift but will buy and gift to somebody else to support.  Great job on this one devs.

I will recommend this game to anyone is a fan of RPG who wants a fun experience without having to spend too much money but to me the game is worth more than there selling it at as a fan of Power Rangers and Super Sentai this game is one of the best times I have had with a game and will be in my top 5 games of this year. It has a interesting and complex combat which will seem simple at a first look but has a hidden complexity with the audience to impress. The game has very loose and meta humour so if that’s not your thing the story may be confusing and annoying.

If there any negatives in my opinion is that you cannot customize the characters and Mecha much. The mecha battle don't add to the audience bar. The update crafting system is improved from the earlier versions but ends up being more difficult to use and I found myself using the store. The final problem is that every time you start a new camping you have to go through the tutorial and due to this makes the beginning of the game a grind.

Even with these problems I love this game and its really worth a go and I am going to end buying it again for Playstation 4 but if you don't feel like buying I am betting on it being a Playstation Plus game or a least small discount even if in my case I feel the game is cheap all ready.

EAT IT SABAN!  This game is awesome.  The writing is hilarious, the mechanics are solid, and the graphics are simple but adorable.  I backed this game on Kickstarter almost two years ago, and it's been worth the weight.  The developers are cool and listen to the community and are actively working on the game.  I can't wait to see what's in store in the future.

Chroma Squad is an outstanding tactical RPG that I highly recommend to anyone who is a fan of Super Sentai, Kamen Rider and a ton of other live action hero shows. The game clocks in about 15 hours (give or take) to complete one play through and is loaded with a ton of fan service and pop culture references that keep you constantly hyped and laughing throughout your journey. The blend of simulation and RPG is where the game truly shines and feels unique. You aren't only creating your dream Sentai team, you are a part of the show!

On the tactical side, the game does not get very complex, and I found the game to be quite a breeze on Normal, but honestly, that's okay. A game does not need to be hard as hell in order to be fun. However, I will note that as hype as the Mecha battles are they are pretty one sided and easy to complete most of the time. From the perspective of a fan of Sentai it makes total sense and you feel awesome beating up Kaiju for the sake of justice, but the above mentioned simplicity is why I couldn't recommend the game to someone just looking for a Tactical RPG fix. Though I would say at the very least look up some footage and if you are open minded enough you might really enjoy it anyways! Might even get you interested into Sentai etc.

Chroma Squad as it is may have relatively simple combat, crafting and business simulation but I strongly feel like that's the entire point of the game. The game doesn't just want you to create a Sentai show, it wants you to be the hero! So what are you waiting for? Get out there and deliver some justice! And don't forget to shout a cheesy line like Justice is best served in a rainbow of colors!" It doesn't have to make sense
date:
as long as you do a cool pose while saying it you'll be FINE.

•	A few annoying bugs

reviewText: If your an absolute fanatic about Power Rangers and its Japanese predecessors then this game is a sure win. Its a love letter built for fans of colorful super hero teams kicking monster ♥♥♥. The story is comical and full of goofy charm, while the RPG-like elements are very fun and keep you engaged in kitting out your team. After a few hours, your team really feels unique. You can even customize their battle phrases, mecha names, and more. Quite a fantastic little game, A+.
So surprised how good this game was. I hope they make a sequel.

Love this game. It harkens back to the good old days of watching power rangers as a kid!
The constant breaking of the 4th wall gives it that good old witty humor that I enjoy so much!
This story is a simple blend of comedy and silliness worthy of a Saturday morning cartoon. The gameplay is simplistic and the crafting element is simple yet satisfying when you finally craft like the ultra best gear. One problem though that I had at least in my experience is that crafting materials (especially the acryliac paint) can be very hard to get. I understand that you can buy boxes that contain these materials however it's hard to get/maintain the funds needed for these things. A small gripe but otherwise this game is a good time!
9/10

This game definitely succeeds in keeping creative thinking alive with interesting story twists, branching paths, and very enjoyable customization.  To be able to make your own super powered team of stunt actors is a joy regardless of whether you're giving them serious or silly names.  The gameplay seemed relatively simple and they surely could have added a few more mechanics (an undo move option would have been VERY useful), but with what they had the game still worked fantastically.  The management aspect seemed rather easy, though my experience was on the normal difficulty setting, so I don't know what it's like on Challenging.  If you like management sims you'll probably learn the mechanics rather quickly and if you like turn based strategy RPGs then there's no reason not to give this a shot.  The game is very enjoyable and has a great amount of replay value.  Give it a shot if you were on the fence about it!

reviewText: Bueno

This game remind me when I was young. I like 5-colors-rangers such as Jet Man, Power Ranger, etc.

Today Chroma Squad bring me my old memory.

The game Chroma Squad simulated you as a director of Sentai TV show, but more than that, you can control your Sentai squad to defeat enemies (both minions and bosses) just like turn-based game. You can upgrade your Sentai suit, gloves, helmet, weapons and much more.

You know, when the boss of episode was died in first place, its will come back alive with bigger version of the boss. So you have to call your Robot to fight with the boss, and yes! you can upgrade your big-robot as well.

If you missing your old memory about your favorited Sentai squad. Just buy this game!

Fantastic Game, in the vein of Fire Emblem, Final Fantasy: Tactics and Ogre Battle series. Control is intutitive and the colours are bright and vibrant - just like the Sentai Shows of old. The humor is solid - if a bit childish, but that didn't stop me guffawing at some of them.

Bugs are to be expected - but so far I've been lucky. Hopefully everything will be all smoothed out in the coming weeks.
I'd buy it just to see how far you'd get on the harder difficulties - or to highlight how ridiculous a team consisting of a Robot, a Cartoon Beaver, an Alien, a Furry and an overweight nerd kicks so much bum.

Overall it's a solid product - one I've glad I've bought.
Now if you'd excuse me, I'm off to direct the Hyper Flare Fighters with their Hyperovercompensator to fight crime, promote justice and just generally geek out with their fans.
This is the best tactics that came out this year, by a country mile.

reviewText: i LOVE this game. my only problem with it is i know its going to end eventually......i really wish there was some kind of random episode generator, or a battle arena or something like that to keep me coming back even after all the endings. thats not to say that there isnt a lot here already, because there certainly is. the writing is wonderful, lines are delivered in a short but sweet comic book dialog box, and you are never quite sure if they team/actors are acting because lots of strange events happen through the story that blurs the line. great story by the way, great gameplay and battle mechanics, lots and lots of customization, from the name of your actors, to the name of their squad (default is chroma squad) and the company of actors, lots of nostalgia, absolutely wonderful pixel graphics, giant mecha fights, special powers, etc, etc. it has LITERALLY everything that you would want or expect out of it. it has yet to fall short in any way in my book. it is a spot on nostalgic power ranger-like tactical RPG, with secondary objectives that will keep you coming back for more. I REALLY REALLY REALLY WISH we had more games like this. the only thing, the one and only thing that i wish they had was some kind of arena or random episode generator.

This game is really fun! As a tokusatsu enthusiast, Chroma Squad really fills most of what tokusatsu games, especially sentai-esque style games must have. There is so much room for improvements, and i really hope that there will be another sequel for this game (Chroma Squad 2! :D).\n\nA must buy!

Only negative thing I'd point out is how the crafting system is now 100% random. You can't go to the store and buy crafting materials to get the crafted items you want. Now you buy a box of random items and if you're not lucky, you could end up never being able to craft better items (or at least Season level items) to up your game for the next battle. Can get a little bit annoying. But you should end up doing just fine in the end.

Chroma Squad is an amazing game where you delve into the makings of a Super Sentai studio. It's like a business tycoon, a tactical RPG, and a customization rainbow stuffed into an amazing masterpiece of a sandwich!

I honestly can't remember how I stumbled across this gem, but when I saw it, I fell in love with it and I had to have it. I'm glad that I did stumble acorss this, 'cuz I've had the funnest time playing Chroma Squad, the most enjoyable game I've come across in a while. In the first week of owning it, this game was what I'd play every night if I wasn't busy. It's extremely addicting, and while the story seems to start out at a good pace, things escalate quickly later on, providing great plot twists that keep the story immensely interesting.

With those opening comments out of the way, let's list the pros and cons.

Pros:
~A great level of customization with a plethora of actors, colors, and equipment to choose from, heck, even the mechs have a good level of customization.
~A great soundtrack. I persoanlly am a big fan of the 8-bit/chiptune style of music, it reminds of the days of arcades and gameboys. Any chiptune lover would listen to the soundtrack over and over again. If you like the music, get the reasonably priced soundtrack. Not only does it help support the devs, but you get to listen to your favorite groovy tunes from the game anytime you want.
~Cool graphics. if you like these kinds of pixely games or pixel art in general, this is a game for you.
~The storyline. I've said it before: It's interesting with a great pace.
~The play time. It took me about 22 hours to get through my first playthrough of the game, on the normal difficulty setting. And that's just for one of 3 endings that the game has to offer. Depending on the difficlty level you're playing and the time spent jamming out to the music, the time to get all the endings can range from 50 hours to 70 hours. Great amount of gameplay.
~The achievements. There's not hundreds of them like their are in other games, and most of them are pretty easy to get, you just need to play the game accordingly. I got over half the achievements on my first playthrough. (Though I guess they could add some ones in the future that require DLC.) If you're not an achievement hunter, that's all right, it could just be a fun side quest. This game has enough play-achievement balance that you don't need to dedicate hundreds of hours to get all of them.
~Difficalty settings. This is always a great feature to have in a game. The difficulties are casual, interesting, and challenging, ehich translates to easy, normal, hard respectively. If you're new to this type of game and/or want to focus on the story, play the game on casual. If you've played these games before and like a nice balance of story and challenge, interesting's your cuppa joe. If you like a challenge, like good planning, and you aren't afraid to lose a little to win a little, challenging is just the right fit.
~Nice balance of battle and management. Not only do you fight with your heroes, you need to check and maintain their gear in order to beat the enemies that get more difficult as time progresses, as well as answer emails from fans, manage production companies, and upgrade your small warehouse studio as time goes on.
~A great price. This game is relatively well priced, and will provide hours of fun and enjoyment that for most of you will be the best entertainment you've had in a while. At 15 American dollars for the game, with 5 additional for the soundtrack DLC, 20 dollars is a great price for this game. (Without DLC, the game is about 10 British pounds, 13 with DLC, for those of you in the UK)

Cons:
~Though the customization is great, it would be a little better if there was more actors to choose form to play your characters.
~Though it has a great storyline, playing it for the second time, at first, can seem kind of repetitive, and I found it hard to emotionally invest myself into the second set of characters. If you feel the same way, I advise taking a break for a month or two, so the shine of this game doesn't get burnt out.
~Dr. Mi ah

Otherwise, this is a great game, and if you were a fan of the Power Rangers when you were a kid, you're going to love this, although prior association is not required for this to be a great game. I personally thought ths was an amazing game.

I give Chroma Squad a 9.7/10

Happy Chromatizing!

reviewText: i LOVE this game. my only problem with it is i know its going to end eventually......i really wish there was some kind of random episode generator, or a battle arena or something like that to keep me coming back even after all the endings. thats not to say that there isnt a lot here already, because there certainly is. the writing is wonderful, lines are delivered in a short but sweet comic book dialog box, and you are never quite sure if they team/actors are acting because lots of strange events happen through the story that blurs the line. great story by the way, great gameplay and battle mechanics, lots and lots of customization, from the name of your actors, to the name of their squad (default is chroma squad) and the company of actors, lots of nostalgia, absolutely wonderful pixel graphics, giant mecha fights, special powers, etc, etc. it has LITERALLY everything that you would want or expect out of it. it has yet to fall short in any way in my book. it is a spot on nostalgic power ranger-like tactical RPG, with secondary objectives that will keep you coming back for more. I REALLY REALLY REALLY WISH we had more games like this. the only thing, the one and only thing that i wish they had was some kind of arena or random episode generator.

reviewText:
Minus the bug in the tutorial stage, this game is pretty damn awesome.  Funny writing, solid tactical mechanics, and amazing art.  Just stick with it guys, even with the bug I'm giving it 5/5.   It'll probably be patched soon anyway.  This is seriously the best ranger game ever.  No joke, this is one of the best tactical RPGs I've ever played - being a Power Rangers fan is just bonus.  The attention to detail is astounding and each episode legitimately feels like an actual episode of MMPR.  You know how the Rangers usually do those flips to get into position?  It's a useful mechanic in this game.  You know how each ranger powers up and pose before doing a special group move?  They do it here :)  And I swear that's Bulk and Skull in the background...

I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

To get pass the bug after the actors quit, just skip the tutorial in the pause menu.  You're missing out on the extra experience you'd gain otherwise, but at least you get to play this amazing game.

ChromaSquad is a fantastic Tactical RPG where you create your very own team of Sentai Warriors. Customizeable to a great level, you can choose your team, each color, team name, catch-phrases, craft your own armor and Mech pieces and more! While simple in mechanics it is noting to sneeze at as it keeps you pumped for the next episode and what may be around the corner.

~
I wish to extend a cordial THANK YOU to the creators of ChromaSquad. It has been a good while since I've immersed myself so deeply into a game. And the absolute charm, fun and personality this game had to offer had me smiling ALL the way through. Right after finishing it I had to start over as it is simply too much fun! And I plan to play your other games and see what more Behold Studios has to offer. <3

This game remind me when I was young. I like 5-colors-rangers such as Jet Man, Power Ranger, etc.

Today Chroma Squad bring me my old memory.

The game Chroma Squad simulated you as a director of Sentai TV show, but more than that, you can control your Sentai squad to defeat enemies (both minions and bosses) just like turn-based game. You can upgrade your Sentai suit, gloves, helmet, weapons and much more.

You know, when the boss of episode was died in first place, its will come back alive with bigger version of the boss. So you have to call your Robot to fight with the boss, and yes! you can upgrade your big-robot as well.

If you missing your old memory about your favorited Sentai squad. Just buy this game!

Fantastic Game, in the vein of Fire Emblem, Final Fantasy: Tactics and Ogre Battle series. Control is intutitive and the colours are bright and vibrant - just like the Sentai Shows of old. The humor is solid - if a bit childish, but that didn't stop me guffawing at some of them.

Bugs are to be expected - but so far I've been lucky. Hopefully everything will be all smoothed out in the coming weeks.
I'd buy it just to see how far you'd get on the harder difficulties - or to highlight how ridiculous a team consisting of a Robot, a Cartoon Beaver, an Alien, a Furry and an overweight nerd kicks so much bum.

Overall it's a solid product - one I've glad I've bought.
Now if you'd excuse me, I'm off to direct the Hyper Flare Fighters with their Hyperovercompensator to fight crime, promote justice and just generally geek out with their fans.
This is the best tactics that came out this year, by a country mile.
Nice little game with a lot of charm. The round based tactics feel smooth, albeit the game could be a little more complex. It makes up for the lack of depth by not taking itself too serious.

Chroma Squad was if anything a blast from the past. The retro graphics, mixed with the power rangers theme brought me back to my childhood. A simpler time. A tactical RPG where you have your own custom power ranger team, you can name the rangers, the team, even choose colors. You also run a studio, purchasing upgrades, signing advertisement contracts, and crafting new gear for the rangers. The script is funny at times, and goofy dumb at others but you'll love it just the same. I clocked in at about 11-12 hours over a couple weeks on normal difficulty.

First of ill just say this game gets 10/10 from me. Got that part out of the way.

Pros: (For me at least)
+Incredibly good sound track
+Vibrant colours and fantastic 16bit (I believe) graphics with fantastic animation
+Run your company how you like with choices of marketing, upgrades to your studio and characters
+Customized team (You can choose your rangers colours and actors (from a set pool of actors)
+Tactical turn based combat
+Teamwork skill allowing team members to coordinate between each other during battle
+You can personalize your company name, the team name and some of their catchphrases
+The Transitmancer
+You can have a pink male ranger

Cons: (Once again personal opinions)
-Not as much choice in episodes (missions) (Though for story purposes i understand why)
-Not very many robot parts to choose from
-Giant robot fights tend to be chance oriented (Which personaly frustrates me at times)

I honestly recommend this game if you enjoy tactical turn based combat and or super sentai.
I hope we get a sequel or successor to this game.

Pros:

-Engaging gameplay
-Plenty of content for replayability (can't wait to unlock the secret Kamen Rider episodes)
-Amazing soundtrack
-Lighthearted story
-Witty and humorous dialog (I love the game's running joke of Director Mi Ah trying to sue for copyright infringement)
-Overall delightful to play

Cons:

-The slight name change of the game
-Saban strong arming Behold Studios into letting the company have some sort of credit in the game (If they didn't, Saban would sue and not allow the game to be released.)

reviewText: What do you get when you cross Heroes of Might & Magic with Power Rangers and a business tycoon simulator? Pretty much this beauty of an 8-bit game. This game combines tactics in two distinctly different ways: The first is managing your indie studio and putting up with all the lawsuits, conspiracy theories, marketing agents, and distinct shortages of PVC and duct tape. The second is the actual green-screen combat with tactical acrobatics, team combos, and all the exploding rainbows a Japanese stuntman hero (or heroine. 10/10 chose Scarlett Johansson as their healer) could ever dream of! There's a lot of humour with terrible acting and some cheeky references across the board, and of course, your very own cardboard Mecha to fight people in suits ravaging the helpless scale model city.\n\nSeriously, grab this game. It's the Power Rangers video game the world never knew it needed.

Very enjoyable game for both the gameplay as well as the story line. If you're looking for a good turn based strategy game (Very reministant of Fire emblem in terms of gameplay) then this is the game you should take a good moment to consider.

Simple Turn-based tactics RPG that brings in a few unique mechanics to the genre.

Gameplay straddles a fine line between making things intuitive but not too simple while giving you just enough but not too much stuff to play around with. The crafting system is multiple layers of RNG buggery and it leaves me with a sour taste in my mouth sometimes.  You can work around it but meh.
The pacing is fairly on point and the game never really overstays its welcome.

There are Super Robot Fights, though it's easily the weakest part of the game currently.  They're also gathering feedback and have announced an overhaul, so this point may become moot in a couple of months.

Aesthetics are colorful with a strong indie feel (it's an indie, kickstarted game so yeah).  16 bit and the like.

The writing assumes that you've watched at least 2-3 episodes of power rangers and have a passing knowledge of certain internet memes that came out within a specific timeframe (I had to google a couple things).  I enjoyed it.  It has the right kind of corn and ham that'll get me to sensibly chuckle most of the time.
and again, the pacing is pretty strong despite the source material.

I highly recommend configuring your super sentai team away from the defaults to fit your preferences as it can greatly improve your gameplay experience.  My team was called the Rude Rollers, they Rolled Out, and my robot was named Pablo Escobar (he shanked giant monsters).

A single run may take like 6-8 hours and there are multiple endings.

A quirky, lighthearted game that brings me back to my childhood of watching Power Rangers while playing Final Fantasy: Tactics Advance on my GBA.

Highly recommended if you want a casual tactical RPG to sink a few hours into with some laughs here and there as our Squad make awful puns.

Only one level in and already enjoying everything about this. The gameplay is what it should be, the characters and story were written with a love for genre that makes me smile; and the theme song made me all kinds of giddy. Can't recomend this enough.

Well-executed tactics game with a variety of mechanics to play around with. Rough around the edges and mostly lacking meaningful dialogue, but it brings some new ideas to the table and I really enjoyed my time with it.\n\nI like the goofy, happy-go-lucky attitude and the deliberately corny special effects even though I've never had any interest in sentai shows.

This game is awesome.
If you enjoy most strategy RPGs you'll love this game. The game plays like if Fire Emblem, XCOM, and Viewtiful Joe had a 3-way and this is the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of that insane relationship. Chroma Squad's soundtrack is also great.
This game is awesome 13/10 would reccomend

This game is exactly what Kickstarter should be about: interesting idea, fantastic development team, and, most importantly, delivery of a finished product.\n\nThe game itself blends a business management simulation on the macro level and a tactical RPG for an episode of the TV series, played for greatest theatrical effect. The animation is simplistic and minimized, but that's okay. This game oozes nostalgia, and coming off as Mario Brothers-esque" is not an insult. Music and graphical interface are smooth
date: but some small issues have arisen with different computers. The biggest selling point is by far the writing; snark and self-referential humor make reading the dialogue part of the experience rather than a chore. As an added bonus
recommended: there is a fast forward option via pressing the enter key. It's one of the many little details that says this studio cares about the fan experience.\n\nThe only real downside I can think of is the menu system: clunky and no real way to make transitions between the various sub menus easier

voteText: the positives outweigh the negatives by several orders of magnitude. Pick this little gem up; even at full price

I immediately fell in love with this game.
When you have hundreds of games to play, it's rare that your attention span is long enough to bear trough an entire game.
But I finished it in one go. It's that good. It's cute, it's funny and very very well made.

You make your own team of sentais, fully customizable, down to the actors, colors, and all the catchphrases.
The gameplay is simple, but very solid and you'll have to carefully planned your move because your opponents are ruthless.

Personal recommendation : go straight to the hardest difficulty even if you have very little experience in strategy games, I only had a tiny bit of trouble with medium.

The game gets ridiculously difficult on the final mission to the point where it's ridiculously hard to actually finish the game. Imagine all the bosses you fought in each mission of the game and now imagine every boss in the game is attacking you all at the same time in the final mission and that's what the final mission is. The bosses in the previous missions in the game were fairly easy but some of them were pretty hard too but then you take every single boss that you've battled in the previous missions and then you put them in the final mission of the game and that is a ridiculous ramp in difficulty that i find to be a bit of bad design.

this game is really fun!! definitely a must for power rangers fans

I have all the qualifications to be part of Chroma Squad. I'm above the age of 18, I have nostalgic memories of old japanese 90ies series.

However I don't fit into a spandex suit. That doesn't matter! I have Chroma Squad, the video game!

It's okay!

It isn't perfect, let's be honest there. It's not a perfect game.

It's got issues with difficulty, it's either a bit too trivial or a bit too hard. The mecha fights are too formulaic. There are rarely any real choices, usually just some very obvious right or good decisions, rather than alternatives.

But despite all that, it's really fun. It hooked me in for the first playthrough, and I'm going back for a second and third because there are alternate endings(though the lack of any option to keep multiple saves DOES mean you need to replay the entire thing... which is kind of a shame). The soundtrack is unbeatably enjoyable and a lot of the jokes are just plain good.

It's clearly a first-time product from an indie studio, it has rough edges, but you can feel that it's full of love despite it, and that makes you love it too. A definite buy if you like goofy humour, bright colours, good music, feel-good stories and isometric tactical combat.

I very much enjoyed the latest incarnation of the XCOM franchise and Chroma Squad scratches that same itch. Squad management, base building, challenging fights, variety of class and stat choices.

The graphics, humor, and plot are pure camp. Which I love.

This was a Kickstarter game I've followed eagerly for a while. Its released was timely and very bug free. I don't think I've encountered a glitch yet.

Cheers to the developers for making something all their own!

Overall this is a fun game. You have several different way to customize your characters and your studio. I am having a blast with this game but the problem is that I am running into two very annoying bugs:

1. Being unable to do anything if an actor or enemy dies in a chain of counter attacks. Killing on a counter attack is fine but if the counter attack is countered and something dies, that is when the game locks up.

2. The final mecha fight outright cashes the game when you launch an attack after a specific point. I am unable to get one of the endings because of this. Thankfully you can have multiple save files so I am going for a different ending.

reviewText:
Minus the bug in the tutorial stage, this game is pretty damn awesome.  Funny writing, solid tactical mechanics, and amazing art.  Just stick with it guys, even with the bug I'm giving it 5/5.   It'll probably be patched soon anyway.  This is seriously the best ranger game ever.  No joke, this is one of the best tactical RPGs I've ever played - being a Power Rangers fan is just bonus.  The attention to detail is astounding and each episode legitimately feels like an actual episode of MMPR.  You know how the Rangers usually do those flips to get into position?  It's a useful mechanic in this game.  You know how each ranger powers up and pose before doing a special group move?  They do it here :)  And I swear that's Bulk and Skull in the background...

I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

To get pass the bug after the actors quit, just skip the tutorial in the pause menu.  You're missing out on the extra experience you'd gain otherwise, but at least you get to play this amazing game.
A rare PC member of tactical RPG family. Challenging (on highest difficulty) and interesting, thought the story sometimes feels like its TOO simplistic.

First game I've played through to the end of in ages. Starting again on Challenging difficulty.\n\nThanks Behold for this wonderful gem! Looking forward to any DLC and changes that may be on the horizon.

First of ill just say this game gets 10/10 from me. Got that part out of the way.

Pros: (For me at least)
+Incredibly good sound track
+Vibrant colours and fantastic 16bit (I believe) graphics with fantastic animation
+Run your company how you like with choices of marketing, upgrades to your studio and characters
+Customized team (You can choose your rangers colours and actors (from a set pool of actors)
+Tactical turn based combat
+Teamwork skill allowing team members to coordinate between each other during battle
+You can personalize your company name, the team name and some of their catchphrases
+The Transitmancer
+You can have a pink male ranger

Cons: (Once again personal opinions)
-Not as much choice in episodes (missions) (Though for story purposes i understand why)
-Not very many robot parts to choose from
-Giant robot fights tend to be chance oriented (Which personaly frustrates me at times)

I honestly recommend this game if you enjoy tactical turn based combat and or super sentai.
I hope we get a sequel or successor to this game.

This game was really fun, and it taught me the about the power of friendship and teamwork. It is a great tribute to the Power Rangers and all Sentai, but also stands on its own as a turn based strategy.

The game is very satirical and at times a bit meta, but it's just to keep things light hearted. I had so much fun crafting new armor and weapons to go along with each team members powers (which get cooler every season you beat). There are plenty of spelling errors, bad grammar and bad puns. You will also find yourself in stereotypical locations and plot devices from the series such as The Park" or "ranger feels bad for hurting the groups feelings somehow".

I only wish the game was harder. On Interesting difficulty I never lost a ground battle
date: and I only repeated a few Mecha battles (yes of course there is a giant robot) because I hadn't figured out the crafting system yet.\n\nOverall great game

reviewText: Very good game. It took me about 10 hours to beat it and I already started a new game to see the alternate endings. The tactics are simple, yet appealing. At first I started to complain about the story , but then I realized how well it served its purpose of simulating a sentai show, enhancing the game experience. It would certainly welcome many things to improve itself, like  diferent paths from the start of the game or a more diverse skill tree for each character, but even so this game is without a doubt a good one from the developers and , even better, has HUGE potential to grow. Looking forward to the mecha rework (and maybe a buff to alien?) 8/10

reviewText: 8/10\nGreat gameplay along with nostalgic references
date: couple of tweeks to mecha combat needed and more diverse storylines wouldnt hurt"\n\nI picked this game up based on the theme and overall design and i am so glad i did! Brilliant references to 90's culture and an interesting tactical RPG combat system make this game very enjoyable. The scenario is you are stunt performers of a super sentai show who decide to make it on your own by kickstarting your own
recommended: the plot then twists from what is a tv show with stunt actors to then turn into something alot more real. The game gives you full control over your cast
hoursPlayed: studio and many other things which makes this game very interesting and different from the norm. With your team of 5 unique classes you can take down foes with a variety of unique moves or work together and form devastating combo attacks. The fact each character is a certain class is a great idea keeping you thinking about what form of attack you will make that will benefit the battle in the long run. Your characters strengths can also be upgraded with an interesting upgrade system
voteText: with a shop you can spend program revenue with to buy stronger equipment or a crafting system in which you can create equipment with drops or purchased materials to help make your characters or mecha stronger. As far as the mecha is concerned it is perhaps the weakest part of this brilliant title
helpfulPercent: although it feels incredible the first couple of times it happens the tactical tile RPG suddenly turns into a 2D fighting mechanic that feels as though it relies on luck far too often. Your accuracy ratio reduces the number of successful hits you make in the same turn
votesHelpful: there were times however where i would hit once have an 85% hit chance and miss finishing my combo. i understand it can happen sometimes but it happened alot more than it probably should have. It made it more frustrating given the fact the enemy monster had the same attack pattern which never missed and then could also do a super attack every few turns made some of these duels long
votesTotal: repetitive and rather frustrating. I feel if the mecha combat was still a tile combat system where you fight in the city it could be made a lot more interesting
votesFunny: whats to say your viewer rating could go down based on the number of detroyed buildings via combat
commentsCount: or using the environment to your advantage. It would certainly make the currently bland mecha combat into something a bit more interesting. The story structure is set in a number of series in which the goal is to increase your fanbase and revenue by putting on an awesome show. You are also in charge of advertising and the studio which can be upgraded to help with the show. The idea of seperate series is great and makes the game into more bitesize chuncks that open up possibilities of extra content later on. With multiple endings the game does have replay value and the episodes in each season can be played in any order desired. The enemy designs are fantastic and some of the stories are great but perhaps more of a mixup with different scenarios would only benefit the game more
column16:
party members could be missing or sub objectives could be more diverse with perhaps saving civilians or dealing with environmental scenarios. This does happen sometimes but maybe not enough.
The soundtrack is a pleasure to listen to and keeps the tempo going. it plays very well along with the artistic style of the game.

Overall the game is a great experience
column17: especially if you are a power rangers/super sentai fan with some great story and combat design and an interesting yet simple upgrade system and tle based RPG combat. More diverse storylines and some work on the mecha battles would only do this game good! If they bring out more content as well this game could be played long into the future.\n\n"

I feel rather disappointed in that I was unaware of this game until long after the Kickstater was met. I'm a fan of sentai series, both american and japanese versions, and I see a lot of genuine love and effort put forth in the game to show off the themes, corny messages & jokes, and tropes that those shows fall into. With that, however, a love of those fanchises is felt through the effort and minor details scattered in the stages, dialogue, and backgrounds. For instance, the statue of JAKQ's 'Big One' in the convention stage or the reference to Doggie Kruger in one of the post-stage tweets. What about the game play? Well, it plays like the tactical RPGs I love (FF Tactics, Disgaea) while still have it's own take and original elements to it. I do wish there was a big more clarity in know what can and can't be done. For example, I didn't know until Episode 3 that I could customize more then the chest of my mech by clicking on the seperate parts. There are some small nuances in the game like that that take me out of the game for a moment as I may have spent my materials differently. Better explanation on fan or income conversion may be nice as well. Overall, I'm very happy with this game and pray the studio learn from this and make their next game bigger and better.
A very cool, shockingly challenging, tactical RPG. Really fun. Great dialogue. A really good laugh. Well recommended.

Just beat it for my first time, it is a fun few hours of gameplay and since they're are multiple endings and diffrent routes I will be playing it once or twice soon to see them. If you love the Power Rangers then this will be extra funny to you I bet. I loved the villain, loved the growth of the characters, I really just loved most of this game. They're are a few issues I have with it though for example it is annoying that if you loose your Assist member you loose 95% of all healing and can never revive anyone unles you Chromatize/power up, and the fact most of the NPC allies aren't seen or mentioned again was a little disapointing though I understood why.
All in all I really loved this game especially when I finished it and got to see the Villains 'dance' to the ending theme, kind of wished your squad was dancing during this as well to celebrate they're job well done but whatever.
If they make a sequel or DLC I am likely to buy it and I am not the biggest fan of PC gaming, but I would love to see if they keep this story going, have the timeline of this game alter the next, or if we get to see the current squad follow something like the power rangers with the changing of powers and rosters because it's mentioned in game that happened before.
Again really love this game and think it is at the least worth a try.

As a huge toku fanboy, I was excited to see a video game based on Super Sentai. One that kept in the spirit of sentai by parodying it, and at the same time, paying tribute to it. I've been following this game since Kickstarter, but only more recently got a chance to buy it with the Steam Sale.

As far as the gameplay goes, it actually managed to exceed my expectations. Everything is controlled by mouse and things like the the teamwork mechanic and skills you can switch out are things I've seen in other games, but this is one of the better ones in recent memory. Teamwork is more than just an extra person to help you attack, you can also use teamwork to get to spaces much farther on the field and pull off specials using it. This really helped me when trying to accomplish the special requirements. The game never felt imbalanced, too, which is awesome because it's the easiest trap to fall in with strategy RPGs.

When you start a new game, you're given the option of picking your team. While I wish there was more options for party members (DLC/Chroma Squad 2?), what characters they do have are very diverse and I think they have just a right amount of options for character selections. The plot itself is the exact same regardless of who you pick, so the main reason to do this is to decide your character's starting stats and which ones you would like to see for the rest of the game, which I really like a lot. The easy way out would have been to just always have them in the suit and choose their stats, or just have your five chosen for you. It even allows there to be a possible lesbian romance later on in the game depending on what gender you pick a certain ranger. Your main five are completely customizable.

As for the story itself, it's not like a mind blowing story or anything like that, but it does it's job of feeling like the power ranger/super sentai shows the game is based on. The end goal is defeating a big bad guy, and on the way, you defeat a ton of different monsters ranging from ridiculous to...well, more ridiculous. There's also trophies, multiple endings, storyline branches, and three difficulties to add some replay value.

There's one place this game falls flat for me, and I don't think it's major, because it only really started to bother me nearing the end. The humor in this game can be funny at times, and then at other times can get a little groan worthy with the memes. I don't mind a lot of the refernces. The non-comedic ones for sentai fans in the weapons/equipment/skills that referenced a bunch of different sentai series all made me smile when I realized the references, and certain jokes work really well. At one point, they reference the What has science done" image with the Seagull with massive biceps

reviewText:
It's a fun, light-hearted game! It's got good (not fantastic) music, a decent set of strategy mechanics, a fun and mostly light story, giant mechs, and an engaging, but lightweight TV show budget simulator

It's a jack-of-all-games. It's a turn based strategy, 2-D mech fighting, TV show simulator.

Though, by the end of the 4th season (out of 5), money management ceases to exist because your set is bankrolled enough to fund the wildest expenditures with ease. Combat is also too easy, with some straight up OP characters and pants-on-head AI. The enemy will spread out it's attacks amongst your team rather than congregating together to fight a single weak enemy, thus losing is almost laughably hard. That being said, team acrobatics, team attacks, and finding the sweet spot with AOE attacks are honestly delightful.

It's not super strategic, but it's a genuinely fun and widely appealing indie game.
