For 15 or even 30 bones, you really can't do much better than Chroma Squad. Even if Power Rangers (or Super Sentai if you INSIST) isn't necessarily your jam, it hits all the right notes for making a good gaming experience through that Triple-A seems to have forgotten; It's fun. Fun. You remember that? You know, when you get giggles or smile? When you get drawn into the experience not because of the spectacle, but because the game directly involves you and lets you make it your own, that's how you make games fun.

Throwing down on some details, here's some specifics of why it's already made my top ten for 2015 -

-Turn-Based strategy, not RPG. Think XCOM: EU, but with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Power Rangers.

-Customisation and upgrades for pretty much EVERYTHING.

-Resource management that's more give-take than just your standard subtraction. It reminds me a lot of how the economy worked in Mechwarrior 2: Mercenaries, a type of economy system I feel got left by the wayside in favour of simpler/easier things that don't add any weight to your decisions.

-Crafting, a system that is notorious for earning my ire by basically being utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t roughly a million per-cent of the time, actually makes some sort of sense in how components are named/what goes into what. It's also not needlessly complicated, which is a gigantic tick in my yes" box.

-It's got good moments of humour in it. It's not a comedy game

Chroma Squad was if anything a blast from the past. The retro graphics, mixed with the power rangers theme brought me back to my childhood. A simpler time. A tactical RPG where you have your own custom power ranger team, you can name the rangers, the team, even choose colors. You also run a studio, purchasing upgrades, signing advertisement contracts, and crafting new gear for the rangers. The script is funny at times, and goofy dumb at others but you'll love it just the same. I clocked in at about 11-12 hours over a couple weeks on normal difficulty.

This game is exactly what Kickstarter should be about: interesting idea, fantastic development team, and, most importantly, delivery of a finished product.\n\nThe game itself blends a business management simulation on the macro level and a tactical RPG for an episode of the TV series, played for greatest theatrical effect. The animation is simplistic and minimized, but that's okay. This game oozes nostalgia, and coming off as Mario Brothers-esque" is not an insult. Music and graphical interface are smooth
date: but some small issues have arisen with different computers. The biggest selling point is by far the writing; snark and self-referential humor make reading the dialogue part of the experience rather than a chore. As an added bonus
recommended: there is a fast forward option via pressing the enter key. It's one of the many little details that says this studio cares about the fan experience.\n\nThe only real downside I can think of is the menu system: clunky and no real way to make transitions between the various sub menus easier
hoursPlayed: but perhaps that is just the nature of a game that puts you in charge of so many details. That being said

reviewText: Power Rangers was a big part of my life in the 90s, and like every kid of that era I remember it fondly even though it is almost painful to sit through now. So, with a good dose of self-aware humor, this game still manages to pay a really well done and loving tribute to the genre as a whole. Everything works in this game, in spite of some minor flaws, and creates an experience worth playing through. This game hit all the right notes for me, and if you are a fan of Power Rangers or old school tactical RPGs then it will probably do the same for you.

This is a nice little game that will keep you busy for about 15-20 hours. I really liked knights of pen and paper (my avatar is from that game) for its graphics and casual game style, and also enjoyed the overall foreign feel with bad grammar and jokes that don't always translate perfectly. This game is sort of the same, but is more linear and less compelling to replay.

As someone growing up watching the power rangers I wanted to go back to some of those cheesy moments and the game really delivers, including the repetitive unispiring boss fights in the form of a minigame. The plot is overall nice and somewhat reminds me of their other work, and there's a nice fast forward effect to skip through the story. TBH I skipped through most of the ending just to finish playing.

I will probably return to this game when a major update is declared and overall don't regret buying it on sale. Thanks Devs for the time put in to writing and styling this!

reviewText: If your an absolute fanatic about Power Rangers and its Japanese predecessors then this game is a sure win. Its a love letter built for fans of colorful super hero teams kicking monster ♥♥♥. The story is comical and full of goofy charm, while the RPG-like elements are very fun and keep you engaged in kitting out your team. After a few hours, your team really feels unique. You can even customize their battle phrases, mecha names, and more. Quite a fantastic little game, A+.
So surprised how good this game was. I hope they make a sequel.

Love this game. It harkens back to the good old days of watching power rangers as a kid!
The constant breaking of the 4th wall gives it that good old witty humor that I enjoy so much!
This story is a simple blend of comedy and silliness worthy of a Saturday morning cartoon. The gameplay is simplistic and the crafting element is simple yet satisfying when you finally craft like the ultra best gear. One problem though that I had at least in my experience is that crafting materials (especially the acryliac paint) can be very hard to get. I understand that you can buy boxes that contain these materials however it's hard to get/maintain the funds needed for these things. A small gripe but otherwise this game is a good time!
9/10

This game definitely succeeds in keeping creative thinking alive with interesting story twists, branching paths, and very enjoyable customization.  To be able to make your own super powered team of stunt actors is a joy regardless of whether you're giving them serious or silly names.  The gameplay seemed relatively simple and they surely could have added a few more mechanics (an undo move option would have been VERY useful), but with what they had the game still worked fantastically.  The management aspect seemed rather easy, though my experience was on the normal difficulty setting, so I don't know what it's like on Challenging.  If you like management sims you'll probably learn the mechanics rather quickly and if you like turn based strategy RPGs then there's no reason not to give this a shot.  The game is very enjoyable and has a great amount of replay value.  Give it a shot if you were on the fence about it!

The Power Rangers simulator you always wanted. One of the best little gems of 2015.

Time to save the world with mild Gymnastics. Chroma Squad is about a small team of stunt men that get sick of thier old boss and deside to start their own Power Rangers like show. The gameplay has you using five different squad members in a grid based arena fighting some waves on enemies and a boss. The game's main difficulty is based on if you choose to the the mission objectives, from hit the boss every turn, win in 5 turns, or finish the boss with a finisher. The game is filled with references that just comes and goes from video games, to pop culture the games has cheesy diologue. The crafting system is somewhat of a mess so I just stick to the shop. The mec combat is bare bone with realy no differences with attacks just the animation that happens. But even with thous complants it acctualy makes the game more true to how a noraml Power Rangers epiosode happens, (story, simple fight, transform, beat boss, boss gets bigger, mec battle, end episode). Overall the campyness and the gameplay make me suggest this game if you have the money and a week end to waist.


P.S. The narrirator spells poorly

reviewText:
It's a fun, light-hearted game! It's got good (not fantastic) music, a decent set of strategy mechanics, a fun and mostly light story, giant mechs, and an engaging, but lightweight TV show budget simulator

It's a jack-of-all-games. It's a turn based strategy, 2-D mech fighting, TV show simulator.

Though, by the end of the 4th season (out of 5), money management ceases to exist because your set is bankrolled enough to fund the wildest expenditures with ease. Combat is also too easy, with some straight up OP characters and pants-on-head AI. The enemy will spread out it's attacks amongst your team rather than congregating together to fight a single weak enemy, thus losing is almost laughably hard. That being said, team acrobatics, team attacks, and finding the sweet spot with AOE attacks are honestly delightful.

It's not super strategic, but it's a genuinely fun and widely appealing indie game.

I am an incredibly lazy and therefore never write reviews even though I play so many video games. I had to take some time out today to write a review for Chroma Squad, though, because this game is pure awesome. This game is a 75 on metacritic and thats a clear under-rating.

Yes, I'll acknowledge that Power Rangers/tokusatsu fanboyism is strong within my heart, but you do NOT have to love Power Rangers to love this game. If you can appreciate a creative tactical RPG with fun, geeky dialogue and story lines, you'll be happy with whatever they are charging for this nowadays. Oh, and choices matter!

Gameplay
The combat system is inventive and really lets the player decide how the battles will go. It's not very complicated, but its still satisfying. Think X-com. You can play with a very basic, methodical approach to the fights, or you can open up and fully utilize all the various weapons/skills in the game. Each of the characters has a particular specialty (like most RPGs) and sunergy is key. Between fights, you'll work on upgrading your characters, equipment, base; this aspect of the game isn't particularly deep, but the developer has adjusted to make it more interesting, in terms of viable options. I would say the Mecha fights are lame, however; good thing there isn't really many of them.

Graphics/Music
I'm not really a fan of pixel graphics and all that, but many people seem to love the pixel art. These are easy to judge for yourself. For this type of game, the graphics aren't important to me. But to be honest, if the game wasn't so much fun, I would probably complain about the character models. I think the environments looks pretty great, though.

The music is pure excellence if you are looking for a fully immersive experience. I tend to turn off music on games and listen to my own stuff, but this is one of the few games that I rolled through using the actual game music.

Story
If you are a Sentai/Power Rangers fan in search of nostalgia, you don't even need this section- it's epic.
If you are not as obsessed with sentai as myself, you will still enjoy the hilarious dialogue and story overall. There are some complaints in this aspect because of the imperfect English (dudes are Brazilian), and also because some of the jokes are dated internet-meme jokes, so if that would annoy you then I suppose you'll need to skip through some dialogue? People who complain about the dialogue have maybe forgotten what the dialogue was like in the shows this is modeled after. The plot will surprise you, even if you don't care about sentai at all.


TLDR
Simplified X-com + Power Rangers + loads of content + multiple storylines = FREAKING AMAZING


Best $15 I have spent this year, and I'm about to buy gift copies for some friends even if they don't wana play it.

reviewText:
As a huge toku fanboy, I was excited to see a video game based on Super Sentai. One that kept in the spirit of sentai by parodying it, and at the same time, paying tribute to it. I've been following this game since Kickstarter, but only more recently got a chance to buy it with the Steam Sale.

As far as the gameplay goes, it actually managed to exceed my expectations. Everything is controlled by mouse and things like the the teamwork mechanic and skills you can switch out are things I've seen in other games, but this is one of the better ones in recent memory. Teamwork is more than just an extra person to help you attack, you can also use teamwork to get to spaces much farther on the field and pull off specials using it. This really helped me when trying to accomplish the special requirements. The game never felt imbalanced, too, which is awesome because it's the easiest trap to fall in with strategy RPGs.

When you start a new game, you're given the option of picking your team. While I wish there was more options for party members (DLC/Chroma Squad 2?), what characters they do have are very diverse and I think they have just a right amount of options for character selections. The plot itself is the exact same regardless of who you pick, so the main reason to do this is to decide your character's starting stats and which ones you would like to see for the rest of the game, which I really like a lot. The easy way out would have been to just always have them in the suit and choose their stats, or just have your five chosen for you. It even allows there to be a possible lesbian romance later on in the game depending on what gender you pick a certain ranger. Your main five are completely customizable.

As for the story itself, it's not like a mind blowing story or anything like that, but it does it's job of feeling like the power ranger/super sentai shows the game is based on. The end goal is defeating a big bad guy, and on the way, you defeat a ton of different monsters ranging from ridiculous to...well, more ridiculous. There's also trophies, multiple endings, storyline branches, and three difficulties to add some replay value.

There's one place this game falls flat for me, and I don't think it's major, because it only really started to bother me nearing the end. The humor in this game can be funny at times, and then at other times can get a little groan worthy with the memes. I don't mind a lot of the refernces. The non-comedic ones for sentai fans in the weapons/equipment/skills that referenced a bunch of different sentai series all made me smile when I realized the references, and certain jokes work really well. At one point, they reference the What has science done" image with the Seagull with massive biceps
date: and jokes like that and the backstreet boys/lady gaga references work really well
hoursPlayed: after meme

votesHelpful: not unlike being in the presence of an middle aged person who goes on Reddit.\n\nStill
votesTotal: I would recommend this to anybody looking for a fun and quirky little RPG. It's definitely worth the price. I still have two more ending paths and minor storyline branches to get

reviewText: If Power Rangers and shows like it were part of your childhood, it is for you. Also it has a catchy theme

Buy it. You don't need a review from me. Wait, you do? Well... alright then.

Pros:
+The dialouge: It's just amazing how many jokes they can state considering the setting is litterally being an indie studio group filming power rangers.

+Stradegy: There's a good amount of it. I'm basing it off of just finishing Season 1, but basically you are given director tasks to appease audience, such as defeating X amount of Y monsters in Z amount of turns, or pulling off finishers on bosses which are very satisfying (when you Chromatize)

+ THE MUSIC: My lord is this the best soundtrack I've heard in a long time. Kudos to the music makers for making such an amazing soundtrack (looking at you A little break from saving the world)

+ Graphics: The graphics is a very vast and colorful pixelated style, and it's very appeasing to the eyes

+ Fan System: Considering it's about an indie group trying to run a show, fans play a major role. They determine how much money you get, and that money goes to upgrading equipment which is the only way (as far as I can tell) to increase your stats.

Cons:
-Crafting Equipment: I'm not knocking off the crafting system, I like it. The only thing that pesters me is that you don't get to see the stat increase or decrease until after you craft it, and once you craft it, you have to hope it does increases with hopefully small decrease in other stats, otherwise you have to recycle it and so far my rng of recycling has been pretty poop.

-Options Menu: Totalbiscuit would probably sue me for doing this since that's his thing.. but the option system is kind of lacking. Sure the requirements would allow even my pc which is viewed as being powered by a potatoe could play it, but the resolutions are kind of hard to navigate and change.. for some reason, you have to let the game go full screen, change the resolution (for me I had to click alot to figure out how to make the slider work), then uncheck full screen, and then it'll save the resolution you want (though for those that play full screen all the time it might not be a problem). But hey at least it has a seperate audio slider for both volume and sfx. ^^

That's about it. The cool thing is that the company is now doing the long task of fixing many bugs... so it's good that they'll keep updating this game. Heck there's even a button to report bugs. So because of that, so will this reveiw if more changes for the better (or worst) occurs.

Chroma Squad is a turn-based strategy game based off of the Power Rangers series. Chroma Squad has 3 different endings and 3 different difficulties.

Chroma Squad has some pros and some cons.

Some positives of this game would be:
This game is short, and has a little bit of replayability.
This game has a few choices you could do.
This game has some comedy in the emails you get after each episode.
You can customize your Squad's names, the mech's name, and what they do after certain things.

Some negatives of this game would be:
This game's endings are all based on what you do on one episode.
Sometimes your game will glitch out and you won't be able to take your turn.

I would rate Chroma Squad an 8/10.

A very fun tacticle RPG with some managment style options and even a split storyline. While not graphicly superior you can still tell the dev tem put a lot of love into this project. To be honest I kept waiting for a sale cause I was unsure, but after missing the last one due to finances (It was steams christmas/New Year sale so i kinda burned a hole in my pocket on other games!) I said buck it all and got it at full price when i had some spare cash. Still not regretting that decision, it's a very fun game!

I'm not a big fan of strategy games.
I haven't watched sentais in more than 15 years.

I immediately fell in love with this game.
When you have hundreds of games to play, it's rare that your attention span is long enough to bear trough an entire game.
But I finished it in one go. It's that good. It's cute, it's funny and very very well made.

You make your own team of sentais, fully customizable, down to the actors, colors, and all the catchphrases.
The gameplay is simple, but very solid and you'll have to carefully planned your move because your opponents are ruthless.

Personal recommendation : go straight to the hardest difficulty even if you have very little experience in strategy games, I only had a tiny bit of trouble with medium.

Suprisingly one of the greatest tactical RPG games I have played in awhile. The concept is intresting and well performed. WOW.

I just finished Chroma Squad and I loved it. I am gonna explain with a couple of keywords what kind of game this is (for those who are considering to buy Chroma Squad):

- Tactical RPG, the tactical form in this game is centered in how you skill your characters (more than positioning).
- Mech fights, YES MECHS.
- Game time, I completed the game in 20 hours.
- Difficulties, there is easy, interesting and challenging. Hardest difficulty is a real ♥♥♥♥♥!
- Managing, beside the tactical RPG side of the game, you need to manage your characters by crafting, teching their skills, upgrading your mech, marketing, responding to e-mail where choices matter (not heavily), upgrading your studio and buying items.
- Achievements, well done compared to most indie games.
- Comedy & awesomeness, this game gave me laughs and goosebumps. Comedy is based on parodies of modern memes, Power Rangers and other silly stuff. I got goosebumps in the final fight, where I just got blown away by the story and momentum of it.
- Story is well done and original.

TL:DR
Chroma squad is an original indie game which has two sides of gameplay: tactical RPG and managing your party. The story is wel done and takes around 15+ hours to complete. I had ALOT OF FUN completing this game and I am happy I bought it. You need to understand the mechanics, but the moment you do its fun as hell.

P.S. Don't craft anything until the later seasons, buying items is the way to go.

A creative tribute to the Tokusatsu genre that many have grown up to or still enjoy. Having team work and acrobatics effect audience levels was an interesting mechanic that allowed to the player to decide on how much of either to do to maximize the attendance to gain more fans/money per episode. The attendance machanic in general seemed a bit easy to abuse to an extent, should have a negative factor if either is overly used.

Having different characters to choose from at the beginning for each role is a really nice touch. It allowed to add in variety to characters with the abilities that affected the gameplay. This allows the player to choose how they would like to play their games, and not have a stagnant gameplay with fixed characters for the storyline only.

Storyline progressed at a decent pace and was well thought out in respect to what Tokusatsu's usually revolved around. But also adding in a bit of flare by blurring reality with fiction.

One thing that was unimpressive after a few levels would be the minion's designs. During a level that had a Boss Mob, could have had the minion's designs centered around that particular Boss in the later stages. It's understandable at the beginning since it is representing the beginning stages of a starter company.

This game is more of a tactical RPG in the mechanics of something like Fire Emblem than a Power Ranger management sim.  You have fixed progression both in the game and in the story.
The game however is enjoyable and is a pretty standard tactics game. It doesn't tell you some information I wish it did ( Enemies movement, your own attack damage, cool downs on enemy abilites), however if you play it on normal or easy the game won't demand that much from you.
Hard should only be played by those willing to obtain massive amounts of salt.

Pros:
Customize your team with various actors, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.
Further customize your characters with various stat-increasing gear choices and weapon types.
Responding to emails seems to provide variation in the storyline, or just give you goodies or fans.
Upgrade your base to provide various buffs to your team.
Optional crafting system; just buy from the store if you can't be bothered.
Winning the fight is only part of the game; try to maximize audience, fans, and income as well.
Light-hearted, otherworldly story with plenty of comedy.
Cons:
Only five party members and predetermined classes limit team customization.
Unable to cancel your movement action, even if you haven't taken any other actions; annoying if you misclick a location, or misjudge distance for a ranged attack.
Characters don't level up, only gaining skills and stats from equipment and progressing through the story seasons"
Since characters don't level up

recommended: you can't grind to level up and make the game easier on yourself even if you want to.\nYou can only see tile markers on tiles you can move or attack to

reviewText: Amazing!! As a child I LOOOOOOOVED power rangers this game is great. Not the best tactical rpg, but that isnt a reason to play it. The reason to play is because it offers a fun game to pass the time based on a genre that is full of nostalgia for many!

The game far exceded my expectations.
I don't need to tell you about the graphics, either you like the chosen style or you don't. FWIW I think they did a great job of having consistent high-quality pixel art.
The sound track is great too!
Story is good, has multiple endings (and the game play is good enough to go through and get them all), good humor, and if you are there just for the tactics, there is a fast-forward though the dialogue.
Game play is excellent.
When I first recieved this game my expectations were that it would be good, but not great, but I figured I might as well give it a try, since I got it.  My intent was to play for just half an hour before bed, since I had to get up early the next day.  The next time i had bothered to look at a clock, nearly four hours had passed. I'll take the old addage about time flying as objective evidence that the game is fun as heck. Since building my new gaming rig, I have actually played it more than any other game.
The game is not perfect.  I have encounted a few bugs (nothing that made it crash, and any complicated software will end up with at least one small bug.)
The games i play over multiple times is limited, this one easily made the short list.
You don't have to be a fan of any of the tv shows that inspired the game, or particularly fond of turnbased strategy games to find the game enjoyable.
The hard difficuly offers a challenge and rewards a strategical approach, medium is more forgiving. It is a game that i think is accessible to a wide audience. For its target audience it offers nostolgia, but It is not inappropriate for younger audiencies and gameplay is approachable to anyone.

Very enjoyable game for both the gameplay as well as the story line. If you're looking for a good turn based strategy game (Very reministant of Fire emblem in terms of gameplay) then this is the game you should take a good moment to consider.

This game is absolutely adorable. The art, writing, music -- it's all just too damn cute. I really love it.

It's not deep -- the strategy is always fairly simple, and towards the end, somewhat repetitive. If you're looking for 90+ hours of customization and grueling, meat-grinding tactical battles, try Wasteland 2 or Xenonauts. But if you're looking for an extremely light-hearted game with nostalgia and adorableness oozing from every pixel, this is a really fun way to blow some hours. The battles ARE occasionally somewhat difficult, too.

I hope these guys go on to make a sequel, and add some depth, additional content, and better crafting/skill balance.

But despite its flaws, it's really worth a play if you've ever been a fan of giant robots, Power Rangers, or simple turn-based strategies.

I have never been a huge Power Rangers fan. I only watched the first 2 or 3 Power Rangers seasons as a kid and I have ignored all other super sentai shows. This game made me regret that I missed out on so much.

+ Solid turn based tactical combat (think XCOM / Banner Saga / Disgaea / etc.)
+ Tongue in cheek humor that will dig its way into your heart
+ Awesome music
+++ Supreme commitment to its theme

- Mecha fights are kind of dull
- Later stages of the game can make side objectives frustrating


It's wacky, it's silly, it's fun, it will remind you of your childhood, the value of friendship, playing around with cardboard and wood back when your imagination had no limit. It oozes so much personality and it manages to both pay tribute to and satirize the super sentai genre and all sorts of other aspects of pop culture. It's a product of deep love and understanding of an entire subculture that most of us are barely aware of but the passion placed behind it transcends the limit of your knowledge and even personal taste to the point where it is impossible not to appreciate what you're seeing before your eyes.

The only reason not to play this game is if you really dislike turn based tactical combat. It's a really good game and an amazing experience overall.
While fairly simple, this RTS/RPG has players fighting not only to win, but winning WITH STYLE.

You could buy this game for the soundtrack alone and you would be getting an incredibly enjoyable, colorful, charming game as a bonus.

Seriously, the battle music is the best I've heard in a very long time and the gameplay is surprisingly complex and interesting.

The fast-forward feature that lets you skip dialog does an effect that looks like you're watching the game on a VCR, which was really well done and very charming. Little touches and flourishes like that really make this game shine and sets it apart from the rest.

A definite must buy.
